They will be in the classrooms with second graders while the third graders are taking what we call third grade gate, that third grade test that they must pass in order to be promoted.

Our MISTER's mentor those students. They also mentor students at the middle school. They will ultimately learn to mentor high school students because that's a part of the goal. It involves mentoring for our MISTER's. It involves exposure. So the traditional teacher ed program the students participate in community service. They participate in the traditional, I guess, situations. We try for the nontraditional. So given that, our MISTER's go to schools. They don't go to just observe. They go and they participate in community service at those schools. They serve as mentors, book buddies, they do ties for tots, different things. So they're gathering a better understanding of the students that will be in their classrooms when they graduate and take on that role as teacher. So we have summer activities that they participate in. We take them places to just make them consciously aware of things. We have the Clemson.

So the whole MISTER program is founded on brotherhood. So the five MISTER's each year, there's a cohort of five that's inducted into the program. Now we have 15. So they're understanding what brotherhood looks like because they're able to see their mentors mentor them. They're able to go to Clemson and see their graduate MISTER's mentor them and then the mentors who are here prepare them for what do they do when they're working with those babies. We also have literacy specialists who come and work with the MISTER's because we want them to address the academic needs of the babies they're working with. We want them to address the social and emotional needs of the babies that they're working with. So a part of that whole big networking system that we have we have a program of trainers who come to help them talk about the social things that the babies go through, the young males, well because they're both males and females in the program. With our S.T.A.R.S. program it's designed for single moms with sons but if a mother qualifies and has a girl then we allow the girl to come onboard. So that's the premise of the MISTER program. It's all about mentoring. It's all about being aware, of being compassionate, having the capacity to address the needs of all of those students that you'll come in contact with as a teacher. We have four who are not Mississippi natives but because it's a scholarship program they have to give at least four years back to Mississippi. So as we look globally, I'm using the term loosely, I mean within the south, so in Mississippi, in Georgia and those areas. As we look at the broader community there's so many things that are different but there are so many things that are common. So that's what we're trying to show them in the effort that it will impact them so regardless of where they are during their four years here.

Yes, they're all designed for, the Through His Eyes program is one where we're bringing another tier to everything that we do. We felt that as we're working grassroots with our MISTER's, with the networks here in the city of Jackson, the Jackson Public School district with the Mississippi Department of Ed, with teachers, with community organizations. We felt that we needed a more national flavor to it. So the Through His Eyes program is one that April 7 and 8th we're going to have national educators, national activists, social activists. We've established a think tank. They're coming to collectively say, okay, with these programs that you have going on, with your teacher ed program at Jackson State, with everything that's going on in the state of Mississippi what is it that we can do. How best can we collectively do it? So in that realm we have Alfred Tatum from the University of Chicago coming. He's the Dean of the College of Education there. We have our state Superintendent of Education, Carey Wright, who serves on the think tank. We have superintendents, local superintendents here from successful and not so successful school districts who are on the think tank. We have our Dean. We have the Deans of all of the HBCU's in the area because we're talking about teacher education and we're talking about making an impact. We have Ivory Toldson from the White House Initiative who will be here. We have David Miller who is renowned for his Raising Him Alone program. We model our S.T.A.R.S. program from his program.

Absolutely. It is a collaborative partnership traditionally serving school districts, communities that surround those school districts and right now young males of color involved in those districts. We are involved in several community outreach programs because you can't address the needs of the child if you aren't addressing the needs of the families and the communities in which they live. So that's what MLI is currently all about. We do that by providing professional development services for the teachers, enrichment activities for the parents and then we network with several entities or institutions within the communities so that there's a network of support for all, for the students, the parents and then even the various institutes. Even if you're a large institution I think about our collaboration with United Way. The United Way in itself couldn't do what United Way does if it did not have the support of agencies within the community. So we do, that's our mantra, collaboration. So it's collaboration at the various levels to address the needs that ultimately refer back to our children, our students.

The Call Me MISTER program is one program that was initiated in 2012 here at the university. It is an outgrowth from Clemson University. They're the founder of the program and we have a chapter here. What that is all about, the Call Me MISTER program, is a program that's designed to place more African American males, young males of color, in classrooms. Too often that is the situation. We have so many students who go through an institution that is so important in their lives without seeing the number of males that they should see.

So it is the intent and purpose of the Call Me MISTER program to do several things, to first address that need, the need for more young males of color in the classrooms. I would tell you yes. Jackson State University graduates the majority of the teachers in this metro and beyond area. You will find them in some of the largest public school systems and especially Jackson Public Schools. We add some public schools all the time. So, yes, we graduate many, many students for the public schools.

here are some students who get into the teacher education programs who have been underprepared based on the experiences that they have had in their previous public schools or private. Then there are other students who are included, transfer students, because they get a large transfer population, who come and seem to be a little bit more ready for the rigor, if you will

If I were to describe Jackson State I would say Jackson State is one of the, well, among the top HBCU's that is striving to develop an image that will be appealing to people period. That's where we're going. We're interested in a global education. We've invested a lot of money in international programs here. We are technology infused. In fact, the former position that I had was just the Dean of Undergraduate Studies. Now with the emphasis on technology and everything that position was repurposed to be the Dean of Undergraduate Students and Cyber Learning. So if you were to visit our library you would see that it's no longer traditional as we know. The first floor is all about how you use technology to improve the teaching and learning process, all the way from innovate, that's an area that teachers can do stuff, create, students can do things and then the faculty development. So Jackson State is really a place now that is getting a whole lot hits about its whole technology infrastructure, its emphasis on engineering because we offer a degree all the way from bachelors to the doctorate. We are looking at the plant facility, the physical facility of this place, how important that is in terms of people making decisions about if I want to matriculate here or if I want my child to matriculate here, how you're concerned about where the kids are going to learn. If there is living and learning where they will learn. So Jackson State is headed in that direction. Last year our enrollment grew 4.5% and that's unusual in the state of Mississippi. So Jackson State has a part of its master plan to have the enrollment of 15,000 in three years, I believe.

So I'm thinking that's what you would think. We are more community focused than we were say five years ago. Back to the outreach part, Jackson State has really, our leadership now believes that the community plays a real role in helping the university to realize its potential. So we have, like I said, that's our part in the school, Blackburn Laboratory Middle School, which is within walking distance. Then, of course, we have sites, we have downtown campus where we're housing the Institute of Covenant and some social work programs, the public service kind of thing. Then

I also think that mentioned how we have a large number of students in the STEM fields and those students are doing outstanding internships with the various agencies. I think you would mention the public service part which ties in with Blueprint for Mississippi.

As you know, in Mississippi the schools are rated in terms of the students' performance on certain standardized measures. And based on how they perform on those assessments that school can be rated either high or low. One of the challenges for the public schools is keeping those ratings above where we can become recognized as a state who really, really prepares students because that's really what those ratings say to the greater community and to the greater work. So one of the challenges is how can the university or how can the College of Education carry this current pedagogy, instructional practices, use of technology in teaching and learning to where the problems are? And that's in the public schools to help them to retool or repurpose those teachers so that they can ensure and they can know when students have truly learned something. How can you move away from the public schools just giving this rote kind of memory kind of thing that has really no application for students and they progress up the ladder.

Our challenge is how do we get more students who are in teacher education to be successful on these licensure assessments the first time around. That's a challenge that we see. The very first time how can we tie that in so closely with all the teacher ed courses that we are monitoring that as we go along. Do you see what I'm saying, so that students will not sit more than once, at least no more than twice for a test when you have taken the courses. I recognize and as I said earlier some of the students come in further behind than others. So I think there needs to be somewhere that can meld into what I'm doing in my coursework. So that's a challenge.

Another thing, another challenge that we have is retaining faculty for the long haul. You may have faculty up there who have been there for the long haul but a lot of them are not in the teacher education area. So now one thing that has helped with that is we have a new chair in early childhood and elementary education who has come from one of our sister schools, Ole Miss, and are energetic, ready to bring what she learned from elsewhere or from preparation. So we hope to see a turnaround with that but that's a challenge that we have. So I'm not sitting here saying all our students are passing the test the first time they take it. I know they don't. They eventually do because you can't graduate unless you do.

Then the other challenge for some of the students who began the matriculation may move to a nonteaching field because I want to graduate. Surely this is not the first time you've hear it. I want to graduate. Then I may come back and take those courses and come to teaching like that. I prefer that you finish your program that you came for rather than just graduating. But that's one of the challenges that we see.

I think one of the biggest problems is taking that information that I have and answering the questions. That's what I think is one of the things. The other thing I think has to do with your preparation in mathematics. A lot of students take the last number of course in high school in math and they need to take the most. So I know math gets them sometimes and I also know doing that analytical thing.

listening to the theories, the how you manage a class and then be able to take that and use it to answer those questions. That's one way. Then the other thing that I see is I don't think we teach the young kids but I don't think we teach the rules of grammar anymore, you know what I'm saying, the language anymore. I think it is expected that we just learn it through some other ways and those questions are on that test.

I saw so many students that I taught in high school. They're grown and everything but this guy came to me and he said are you still having the students to conjugate the verb to be? You know I've never learned how to conjugate that verb. I said, no, I don't teach that anymore but he remembered. He said, yes, I remember. He really made me a better writer. I didn't do the to be verb but I did some of the other verbs. I thought that was interesting because that had to have been 25 years ago. So that was interesting. But back to what you were saying, I think those are some of the problems. You must know how the language is put together and you must be able to know what is the overarching thought here and you must be able to pick out that that has nothing to do with that. So aligning the curriculum with the things that they must have may be one of the problems. The Praxis probably won't set in but they may be one of the problems.
students are advised and are taken the courses in a sequential order so that those skills build.

understanding the demographic conditions, the population of the San Joaquin Valley, and how that is driving CSUs particularly in the San Joaquin Valley to adjust, to focus, to serve in new, better, different, ways this changing demographic, which is largely a Latino story when you drill down into it
significant is the growth of the Southeast Asian population in the San Joaquin Valley, particularly Hmong.

You may be familiar with the San Joaquin Valley, maybe not, but it is a large, large, agricultural and rural area. We have many, many, great schools in the San Joaquin Valley but one of the things about the education system in general is you know they're not all even.

So, San Joaquin Valley, while it has great schools in the K-12 sector, it's challenged by some being largely, largely, minority, underrepresented minority, many largely agricultural areas, and poor, poorer. So this is our challenge in the San Joaquin Valley to serve that population.
One of the problems, one of the issues is that in the San Joaquin Valley, it's not an affluent region.

So they're, some folks say that they're place-bound, or geographic-bound, Stanislaus to the north, Bakersfield to the south, Fresno right in the middle, we're the home. We're the home for many of our students.

So I think statewide students have been struggling with this for a long time. What's different is now Fresno State is going to be part of that environment where we have to manage our resources in different ways, and we have to increase, improve, our communications to all of those folks who are charged with outreach services, advising relationships, working with that high school. Yes, we're going to have to do all of that.

My thing is having growing up in the San Joaquin Valley, then worked in southern California for a long time, then coming back and investing here, is I see the San Joaquin Valley as like the last economic frontier in California really, and a great agricultural region, and we do say CSU is an economic engine for the state.

Challenged by some being largely, largely, minority, underrepresented minority, many largely agricultural areas, and poor, poorer. So this is our challenge in the San Joaquin Valley to serve that population. Our K-12 friends at -0:06:33.5- schools, they're pressed really, really, hard as well to raise the preparation levels of this population.
completion of A-G subjects and a certain level of SAT, a certain level of GPA, and Admissions, then they're deemed CSU eligible. Well, that has been a great challenge for our K-12 counterparts

We cannot meet the demand. The demand to get in is exceeding our supply of classrooms, faculty, and all of that, because on the retrenchment side, to receive only 1% growth money each year is just token. It's not doing it. So for the past four years in particular, Fresno State has been denying fully CSU eligible students, denying. There's no space. So four years ago was like 2000 and 3000, 4000. So this coming fall '15, we estimate more than 5000 will be CSU eligible but denied, no space.

In fact, in the CSU, as we go through this impaction issue that's come up, of the 23 campuses, we will now be campus number 17 that has to manage enrollment in different ways. We cannot have seats for everyone.

So, community college system, with passage of a few years ago, not too long ago, SB1440, are you familiar with that legislation? It guarantees if the community college student has their SA or AA degree, they're guaranteed a seat in the CSU in good standing and all that, they're guaranteed a seat. So that's the funnel. So it's more difficult these days for first time Freshman to go directly from high school. I mean they get in. we still admit more than 3000. This past fall was 3500, and that was like a high mark. But we can't do 3500 again this next fall. We got penalized for doing 3500. We had to pay back, so we were penalized money. We had to pay back because we went over enrollment. So we have to bring that now down to 3200, 3100, alright, but then each year the number of applications grows by several thousand.

So the way for students to achieve success is high school needs to make sure that they do what they have to so the students are prepared. Those who are 3.5, 3.8, 4.0, I mean they're going to get in where they want to go. But those who are in the 3.0, 2.5, that marginal, community college, prep, get the preparation, knock down those remediation issues. From our community colleges that come in here, remediation in English need, remediation in Math need is practically 0, 0 or 1%, real low. But for first time Freshman coming in, it's 40-50%.

So I think statewide students have been struggling with this for a long time. What's different is now Fresno State is going to be part of that environment where we have to manage our resources in different ways, and we have to increase, improve, our communications to all of those folks who are charged with outreach services, advising relationships, working with that high school. Yes, we're going to have to do all of that.

The CSU master plan established enrolment caps, ceilings, for all of the CSUs. Starting back in the 60's. And they revisit it, I don't know when the last time it was revisited here, but for the schools in the San Joaquin Valley, they haven't been, they haven't changed in decades.

majority of our students stay, alright, they're place-bound. They're born here. They're grown here. They have jobs here. They have family, extended families, and all that kind … they're not as mobile as those in southern California or the Bay area.
In California, we have what's called the A-G subject areas.

In K-12, high school graduates, or high schoolers who are going, who are intending to enroll in the CSU or the UC, in order to prepare must complete what are called the A-G subject areas. And A, there are some that are focused on science, some are focused on math, social sciences, and on and on. But the A-G subject area is comprised those advanced college prep type courses. So when we receive an applicant, first time Freshman applicant, those are the things that Admissions is going to take a look at, not just us but everybody across the state universities look at the completion of these courses, and how well they are doing. So our eligibility index then requires completion of A-G subjects and a certain level of SAT, a certain level of GPA, and Admissions, then they're deemed CSU eligible

Very diverse. Here in Fresno you have a lot of diversity within migrants. You have the here to work type of students like me who came from either Mexico, Salvador, Central America or anywhere else but they came here to work. They did not come here to study. So they land in the fields. The migrant education program reaches out to them in the fields. It provides them with an opportunity to earn their high school degree in a nontraditional manner.

That was CAMP, College Assistance Migrant Program. That was 1986. One year later I was part of, he and I decided you know what we have way too many students. It's time to develop a bigger program and this is the result. We developed this program in 1987. It's been in development ever since because the students are changing. Now today we have the majority are undocumented students. When we started this program it was also majority undocumented. Back then we knew them as -0:25:57- students. You probably don't know. You're probably too young to know that. -0:26:01- was like AB-540 now except back then it was a court order versus legislation. So it was the legal way for students to come into the university but that was killed in 1994 by Governor Wilson. So from 1994 to 2001 it was the most difficult time in my program years because I had no legislation on my side to help my students get into the university. We have to be extremely creative to get the students in.

But during those seven years when we had no legislation, you know it's interesting because I thought that it was going to close and all I had to do was study more in-depth the admissions requirements. I learned that to come to Fresno State you can give residence status through your parents. I said here is the answer. So all of my students started coming in under their parents to get residency. It was just a different way of doing the paperwork. So I never, I always had a good pool of students but it skyrocketed just a few years ago with the California DREAM Act became a law, which was about four years ago. Oh, my God, skyrocketed. Today I have, right now I have 500 undocumented students on campus. I have 302 applying for next semester. I have 750 wanting to apply for next year at Fresno City College. I have 640 wanting to apply from Reedley College.

Then you have the others where the whole entire family migrated but they are undocumented. Because they are undocumented they have been flying under the radar all of their lives. So they purposely stayed out until somebody later in high school told them hey you have an opportunity to go to college. They say really? Yes. It's legal. It's all legal. California has legislation that allows you to do that. Once they hear that it's all legal they come out of the shadows. The numbers are skyrocketing right now because we have California legislation. Several, there's about five different California legislations that make up what we call in California the California DREAM Act. That includes AB-540, AB-130, AB-131, SB-1159, AB-2000, all of those together make the California DREAM Act. It's so good that beginning next year students with no documents are going to be able to work in California through a license because the state is going to start issuing the licenses. That's beautiful. That is beautiful.

I was a migrant myself. So we migrated from Mexico. I came here to work. Even with the migrant they recruited me back in high school. I did go to high school but I learned that in high school I got put in the back of the room and would not see students so I dropped out. But the migrant program didn't give up. They went to visit me at home and asked my parents why don't you send Raul to school. My father in all of his wisdom just told them why don't you ask him. So they went to me and said why don't you go to school and I said what do you want me in school for? I don't want to go to school if I'm going to be sitting in the back of the room. I can do better than that. I can do better things with my time than sitting in the back of the room. I can go the fields and I can make some money to help my family. I don't need to waste my time going back to school like that. So then the recruiter asked me a critical question. What is it going to take for me to take you back to school? At the spur of the moment I said well give me a tutor and I'll go back. And he did. He gave me a tutor. So I said oh I guess what I wanted now. I've got no excuses. So that's what took me to get back to school, a personal tutor, a person that would pay attention to my needs. It wasn't that easy because of the bullying. Bullying was never addressed by the migrant program. I just survived on my own.

That was CAMP, College Assistance Migrant Program. That was 1986. One year later I was part of, he and I decided you know what we have way too many students. It's time to develop a bigger program and this is the result. We developed this program in 1987. It's been in development ever since because the students are changing. Now today we have the majority are undocumented students. When we started this program it was also majority undocumented. Back then we knew them as -0:25:57- students. You probably don't know. You're probably too young to know that. -0:26:01- was like AB-540 now except back then it was a court order versus legislation. So it was the legal way for students to come into the university but that was killed in 1994 by Governor Wilson. So from 1994 to 2001 it was the most difficult time in my program years because I had no legislation on my side to help my students get into the university. We have to be extremely creative to get the students in.

But during those seven years when we had no legislation, you know it's interesting because I thought that it was going to close and all I had to do was study more in-depth the admissions requirements. I learned that to come to Fresno State you can give residence status through your parents. I said here is the answer. So all of my students started coming in under their parents to get residency. It was just a different way of doing the paperwork. So I never, I always had a good pool of students but it skyrocketed just a few years ago with the California DREAM Act became a law, which was about four years ago. Oh, my God, skyrocketed. Today I have, right now I have 500 undocumented students on campus. I have 302 applying for next semester. I have 750 wanting to apply for next year at Fresno City College. I have 640 wanting to apply from Reedley College.

So what I'm trying to do is to now my new partner is the President of the university. I love that man because he just started the university just he's been here one year. I went to him. I exposed to him what I am exposing to you and after an hour he says, “Raul, I'm sold. What do you want me to do?” I said, “Put me on your sacred cow list.” And to my surprise he said, “Deal.” So up to now we are on the top three priorities for him. He has been very vocal about it. He said AB-540 students, foster students and I forgot the third group. But those are the three groups that nobody touches. We're going to do whatever it takes to keep them on campus. So he loves my students as much as he loves the foster students but he's not afraid. He will put us at the forefront. That has opened the door for more partnerships and more support. Unfortunately, that means more work for me. It's kind of those things be careful what you ask for because you might get it. I asked for support and now I'm getting it. It's like okay now we have to do more.

The Hmong students is more of a challenge. The family dynamics are different. I think the family ties are much stronger in the Hmong community, especially for the females. The Hmong females they have it tough. They have it tough. They are pretty much not forced but driven into relationships way too early in their lives. Then when they become and they get into a relationship and they get into it and now they belong to this other family. They literally belong to this other family. So their dynamics are much tougher, much tougher. I have not found the answer to working with them. The best I have done is develop programs and I always have an underlying message in the programs saying from Hmong to Hmong.

For a Hmong student, the pressure for a Hmong student to come to this school is much higher than for one of our students. You can ask any Hmong student that question, especially the females. The expectation is super high. If you're not going to do good in school then you're not representing the family well. You're wasting everybody's time. Everybody. Not your time, it's everybody's time. In our families we're not as into that as much. We let it go a little more. But for them it's a family issue. For us it's also a family issue because we do put pressure on them, especially money wise. But if they don't do good we don't take it as a family offense. You just don't make it. Go get a job. But my Hmong students they do feel the pressure. Pressure is the number one, family pressure is on top of the list for them.

Here in Fresno you have a lot of diversity within migrants. You have the here to work type of students like me who came from either Mexico, Salvador, Central America or anywhere else but they came here to work. They did not come here to study. So they land in the fields. The migrant education program reaches out to them in the fields. It provides them with an opportunity to earn their high school degree in a nontraditional manner. So that's the first catch. I tend to work with them a lot. I always say my students take me wherever they have activities so that they not only hear about the opportunity to complete high school but also hear about the opportunity to go to college at the same time. So you have a lot of those kids that are here to work. They typically don't come with family. They come on their own.

So you have the undocumented students. But then you also have the children of farm workers who are permanent residents but they were born here. We have a lot of them too. A lot of the kids they are bilingual with Spanish still their primary language. Their English is pretty good because they were born here so they acquired the language a little better. The number of the students that are in that position is also significant. In my program I would say like 45% are undocumented, another 40% are children, US born citizen but children of farm workers and the other 15% are either permanent residents or from another ethnic group.

The Hmong students is more of a challenge. The family dynamics are different. I think the family ties are much stronger in the Hmong community, especially for the females. The Hmong females they have it tough. They have it tough. They are pretty much not forced but driven into relationships way too early in their lives. Then when they become and they get into a relationship and they get into it and now they belong to this other family. They literally belong to this other family. So their dynamics are much tougher, much tougher. I have not found the answer to working with them. The best I have done is develop programs and I always have an underlying message in the programs saying from Hmong to Hmong.

: That means I do not, I am not the one that delivers. I get a Hmong counselor to talk to a Hmong family. If a Hmong family is to come to Fresno State I'm not the one. I get one of my Hmong students take them around. That's the best I have done from Hmong to Hmong. It becomes a cultural thing. I have a father's retreat only for men. That's another cultural thing. I do the one for the Spanish speaking migrants but for the Hmong I don't do that. I train the counselors but then the counselors have to go from Hmong counselors to the Hmong population. It's very different. The graduation, man, they dress up. I don't know if you have ever gone to their ceremonies but they go all out. They really dress up. I mean for us to finish, one weekend of activities and for my parents they didn't dress up. We just went and got the certificate. For them, no, they have to go in their traditional clothing. It's culturally, to them it meant more. It also meant a lot to our parents but our parents were much more comfortable, I guess. They didn't see it as a big deal to complete a leadership training for parents. It wasn't as much of a big deal for the Spanish speaker but for the Hmong speaker, for the Hmong community it was a big deal.

Here I went to Le Grand High School. It's about 60 miles north. I went to Merced College. After Merced College came to Fresno State and that's when I learned that there was something for me to do here. I love what I do. I have the best job.

He had an interview here at Fresno State but he didn't want to come alone. He needed somebody just to come with him. So being a friend he said, “Hey, come with me. Just come with me.” I said, “Okay, I'll go be your bodyguard.” I came here and I sat outside the administration and said, “Okay, you go. He says, “No, no, no, come with me. Yes, you can sit there with me. Just sit with me, okay?” I said, “Okay, fine.” I went upstairs and I sat and he went to his interview. I'm sitting outside and then the director comes out and says, “What are you doing here?” “I'm waiting for a friend of mine.” “Are you applying?” I said, “No, I'm not.” He says to me, “Why not?” “Because I'm not.” He insisted. “How come you're not applying?” I said, “I'm probably not going to get admitted.” He said, “You know what, I'm the Director. You apply and I will admit you.” “Really? Okay, I'll give it a shot.” So I completed the application right there, turned my application in and right away he called me. Do an interview with this counselor and at the end I walk out and then he comes out to tell me that I was not recommended. That tears me up. He didn't recommend me for admission to the university because of my language challenge. That was his excuse. He said linguistically he is not ready. I was mad. So I waited and I said, “I've got to see the Director.” So he came out and said, “What happened?” I said, “You know what, I don't like what you did to me. You made me do this application process just for you guys to tell me that I'm not admitted? I don't need this stuff.” He said, “Really? You were not recommended?” Yeah. So the secretary gives him the paper work and he says, “Come to my office.” So I went to his office. “Look what I'm going to do.” He puts ‘admitted.' I go, “Oh, what does that mean?” “You're ready to come to college.” His name is Robert Hernandez. He just retired. But he's the one that got me into the university. I didn't attempt. I don't know if it was coincidence or

Yeah. So I hit my goal but God had something different for me. So I was teaching a couple of classes called English as a Foreign Language here on campus. In just one day I'm walking up to my apartment and this man was trying to put a sofa into his truck. So I offer help and he said, “Oh, please.” So I helped him put it on and after that he offers me a soda. And so he asks me, “So, what do you do?” I said, “I'm teaching English as a foreign language.” He said, “What's your major?” “Linguistics.” He said, “What do you do there?” I said, “Well, I help the students that are trying to learn proper English.” “Oh, my God.” He said, “This is God in the making. I need you in my program.” “Why?” “I have about 42 students that need your help. So I want you to work for me.” I said, “I can't. I'm already teaching two classes and I'm in the master's degree program.” He said, “I don't care. You come to my office.” I said, “I can't work. I already have two classes.” He didn't give up. He says, “No, I want you in my office tomorrow.” So I showed up to his office and I tell him and he interviews me. He says, “I want you in my program.” And again I insist to him. I said, “I can't. I have a responsibility and I'm not going to let them down.” He said, “Well, now they can love you more. What if I give you flexibility to complete those classes while you can give me at least 15 hours a week?” So I did and I never left.

a student comes to Fresno State. They want to be teachers. You put them to be teacher assistants. That just makes such great sense. It's common sense. Why don't we do the same with the students in criminology, the students in electrical engineering? Why don't we do that? It improves and helps in retention.

The key to survival is collaboration, partnering. My number one partners are admissions. They have always been my partners because if I help the students in now I have a reason to be here. My second partner is financial aid. My third partner is scholarships. My fourth partnership is anyone that give my students a job, beginning with mini corps, teaching fellows, Pathways, community service programs, career services, agriculture. They offer some good scholarships. So partnerships is really the key to success.

Well, my first job is to help them understand that they have an opportunity to go to the university. So it's access and promotion. I do that by utilizing media, traditional media, television and radio but I also use the social media and making a whole lot of presentations, a whole lot of presentations.

I was a migrant myself. So we migrated from Mexico. I came here to work. Even with the migrant they recruited me back in high school. I did go to high school but I learned that in high school I got put in the back of the room and would not see students so I dropped out. But the migrant program didn't give up. They went to visit me at home and asked my parents why don't you send Raul to school. My father in all of his wisdom just told them why don't you ask him. So they went to me and said why don't you go to school and I said what do you want me in school for? I don't want to go to school if I'm going to be sitting in the back of the room. I can do better than that. I can do better things with my time than sitting in the back of the room. I can go the fields and I can make some money to help my family. I don't need to waste my time going back to school like that. So then the recruiter asked me a critical question. What is it going to take for me to take you back to school? At the spur of the moment I said well give me a tutor and I'll go back. And he did. He gave me a tutor. So I said oh I guess what I wanted now. I've got no excuses. So that's what took me to get back to school, a personal tutor, a person that would pay attention to my needs. It wasn't that easy because of the bullying. Bullying was never addressed by the migrant program. I just survived on my own.

I know it still happens. I know it still happens. One of the things that, the only reason why I went back to high school was to thank my ESL teacher because her classroom was the safe haven for me. The only place where I could avoid the bullying was in that classroom.

Because it was in the classroom. Outside they were pushing me, they would do whatever they wanted with me. So I would stay as close, I was the kid that you would find sitting, if you were the teacher and this is your classroom you would find me sitting right outside the door. Not because I loved the teacher or I loved the class but it was because that was the closest to my safe haven so I could avoid bullying. So I always thank the teachers that opened their classrooms, especially during lunchtime.

The reason why I put an emphasis on funded by the university is because when I am funded by University of Fresno versus a grant it allows me to serve the students that come to Fresno State. One of my primary groups is the undocumented students, the AB-540 students. That's how we call them in California because of the legislation 9540. But I also serve the US born migrant students, those that come from parents that are doing farm working and a few that are permanent residents. But the majority are the undocumented AB-540 students. The second large group is the US born migrant students and a few are permanent. I want to shrink that because I want to make them citizens.

My program here at the university is called University Migrant Services. My task is number one to provide access to them, open the door so that they can apply to the university or better yet prepare for the university on a timely manner. I do so by coordinating efforts with programs like California Mini Corps, with programs like the Migrant Education K-12 programs but I go beyond that. I also coordinate with our regular school districts because a lot of my students are not “migrant” because I don't follow the definition that they have in the K-12. I follow more the farm worker background definition and because of that a lot of my students are in English learner programs in the school districts. So I have to partner with them to provide opportunities for these students to prepare for and qualify as a regular average student when they come to apply to Fresno State. It's a lot of efforts but I do care. I've been here a long time so I have the luxury of being the dinosaur here on campus.

my first job is to help them understand that they have an opportunity to go to the university. So it's access and promotion. I do that by utilizing media, traditional media, television and radio but I also use the social media and making a whole lot of presentations, a whole lot of presentations.

mini corps is a sister program to me. Mini corps belongs to the Migrant Education K-12 Program funded by them. The national program funds mini corps at the national level and then each state also has their own. It channels down to states. In California we have the largest, California Mini Corps. Then California is so large. It's the largest program population wise for in terms of students and they break it into regions. There's 25 regions. Fresno happens to be the largest mini corps program in the entire United States because we have two programs at the university not one.
The K-12 migrant programs provide summer classes or summer experiences or weekend experiences.

Then you have the others where the whole entire family migrated but they are undocumented. Because they are undocumented they have been flying under the radar all of their lives. So they purposely stayed out until somebody later in high school told them hey you have an opportunity to go to college. They say really? Yes. It's legal. It's all legal. California has legislation that allows you to do that. Once they hear that it's all legal they come out of the shadows. The numbers are skyrocketing right now because we have California legislation. Several, there's about five different California legislations that make up what we call in California the California DREAM Act. That includes AB-540, AB-130, AB-131, SB-1159, AB-2000, all of those together make the California DREAM Act. It's so good that beginning next year students with no documents are going to be able to work in California through a license because the state is going to start issuing the licenses.

CAMP, College Assistance Migrant Program. That was 1986. One year later I was part of, he and I decided you know what we have way too many students. It's time to develop a bigger program and this is the result. We developed this program in 1987. It's been in development ever since because the students are changing. Now today we have the majority are undocumented students. When we started this program it was also majority undocumented. Back then we knew them as -0:25:57- students. You probably don't know. You're probably too young to know that. -0:26:01- was like AB-540 now except back then it was a court order versus legislation. So it was the legal way for students to come into the university but that was killed in 1994 by Governor Wilson. So from 1994 to 2001 it was the most difficult time in my program years because I had no legislation on my side to help my students get into the university. We have to be extremely creative to get the students in.

The key to survival is collaboration, partnering. My number one partners are admissions. They have always been my partners because if I help the students in now I have a reason to be here. My second partner is financial aid. My third partner is scholarships. My fourth partnership is anyone that give my students a job, beginning with mini corps, teaching fellows, Pathways, community service programs, career services, agriculture. They offer some good scholarships. So partnerships is really the key to success.

For a Hmong student, the pressure for a Hmong student to come to this school is much higher than for one of our students. You can ask any Hmong student that question, especially the females. The expectation is super high. If you're not going to do good in school then you're not representing the family well. You're wasting everybody's time. Everybody. Not your time, it's everybody's time. In our families we're not as into that as much. We let it go a little more. But for them it's a family issue. For us it's also a family issue because we do put pressure on them, especially money wise. But if they don't do good we don't take it as a family offense. You just don't make it. Go get a job. But my Hmong students they do feel the pressure. Pressure is the number one, family pressure is on top of the list for them.

The second largest job that I have is helping them through the application process. It's not easy. Helping them do all of the paperwork during their senior year of high school is a challenge. One, they don't know what they're doing. Two, a senior experience in high school just is a difficult time to work because they are so excited about grading from high school.

Here in Fresno you have a lot of diversity within migrants. You have the here to work type of students like me who came from either Mexico, Salvador, Central America or anywhere else but they came here to work. They did not come here to study. So that's the first catch. I tend to work with them a lot. I always say my students take me wherever they have activities so that they not only hear about the opportunity to complete high school but also hear about the opportunity to go to college at the same time. So you have a lot of those kids that are here to work. They typically don't come with family. They come on their own.

That's beautiful. That is beautiful.

So what I'm trying to do is to now my new partner is the President of the university. I love that man because he just started the university just he's been here one year. I went to him. I exposed to him what I am exposing to you and after an hour he says, “Raul, I'm sold. What do you want me to do?” I said, “Put me on your sacred cow list.” And to my surprise he said, “Deal.” So up to now we are on the top three priorities for him. He has been very vocal about it. He said AB-540 students, foster students and I forgot the third group. But those are the three groups that nobody touches. We're going to do whatever it takes to keep them on campus. So he loves my students as much as he loves the foster students but he's not afraid. He will put us at the forefront. That has opened the door for more partnerships and more support. Unfortunately, that means more work for me. It's kind of those things be careful what you ask for because you might get it. I asked for support and now I'm getting it. It's like okay now we have to do more.

I started my own foundation because I have way too many students coming to me that are not in Fresno State. So in order to help them I had to start a foundation and really helping the students. Number one priority at the foundation is help the students get their Deferred Action. We have helped more than 2,000 students get their Deferred Action documents here in the area. Right now we are waiting for the new Executive Action. Hopefully the Appeals Court overturns the ruling from that judge. But if that happens we are ready. I have a crew of about 50 already trained graduate students to go out there and help my students, to help everybody get those documents. To me that has become priority.

I came here, it's interesting. People think that reservation is so dysfunctional. But when I came here I had just over four or five years I had lost my father, two children and my husband. So I was kind of a wounded healer. But through teaching these kinds of classes and everybody listened. I told them I had the perfect job because I could talk and they had to listen. I actually was, we had a workshop one day and I was like oh I've been healed, I mean by the community because they listened. That's kind of how I got here.

So I think when you're trying to bring people of color to teach their own students because some people are just too white. Some people can cross the line but some cannot. It's kind of like if you want to work with another culture you have to become kind of marginal in your own culture so that you can connect to their culture. Some people are just, they just cannot move of front and center of their own culture. That's really part of the problem.

F: Yes, challenges. Students, Native students are not white students. They are not, you know, all of education basically is geared towards European knowledge, whatever. Okay, so we're trying to fit Native people into this mold. Reality is like the poverty stuff. It really kind of hits a lot of it too. A lot of them come from poverty so they have that type of thinking, that type of mentality. School is middle class, saving, it's that work hard today and you'll get better and do better tomorrow. In their world it's more like in the moment or the humor, whatever. If they fall apart instead of just keep on trucking they will fall apart for two or three weeks or whatever and then suddenly come back and like oh I just want to start where I left off. So they don't have that strength, I guess.

ou strip them of their will to scramble around and to stand up and to figure out, to pull it in and say okay this is who I am and this is my spot in the universe. You don't do that. You only do that when pain or something gets you, makes you move versus if it's kind of handed to you then oh well okay they want you to jump through this hoop and this is what I'm going to do to get this but the hoops are all white. Pretty much. That's called genocide. I mean it's just a kinder form of and I don't even know if they understand all of that or where that really comes from. I work with some pretty harsh people because I do different things too like Journey with a Drum or different kinds of things. That kind of knowledge is a little bit different that your European, than your education. Natives if they want to truly be Native it's not the easiest life. It's a really strong mastery, a really strong life. Heaven knows they have enough dysfunction that they should be able to use to pick that up but the handouts don't really or we have this tribal government scandal or whatever. That greed that's not me. That's kind of basically from European materialistic point of view.

Native teachers really need to but pretty much our work is you need to be healed and know who you are first and then you will be excellent to teach Native kids. Then Native kids can have role models. Role models are really something that's kind of lacking. The drug dealers make more money that the whatever or the tribal council that steal money or whatever. I mean those are the role models that kids see. They don't see in the classroom and there's been some excellent teachers over there that are white that did care. Most of the time they end up leaving because they can't fight the system. The system is difficult.

So I think when you're trying to bring people of color to teach their own students because some people are just too white. Some people can cross the line but some cannot. It's kind of like if you want to work with another culture you have to become kind of marginal in your own culture so that you can connect to their culture. Some people are just, they just cannot move of front and center of their own culture. That's really part of the problem.

And sometimes you forget that you're the teacher and not the learner. In my style I mean I have to teach too but a lot of what I do is do healing. I think classrooms are great places to heal and great places to put a lot of information out. They don't have to take it personal. You just put it out there and they can see oh yeah. I think it works better for Natives if you use your story to teach because then they can always see. They're great at that circular story. I use my life basically to teach a lot of lessons or a lot of things. Of course that helps me too because then I can lay it out there and look too. That's one of the things.

they allow us the freedom to decide exactly how we're going to implement that and then they provide us with whatever support that we needs. So here at Jackson State basically what we do, again, we have it set up where the initial year that they come in we work with the students. Again, we get them set up with mentors out in the schools. We also provide them with experiences to serve and working with young kids along with taking their courses. We utilize the cohort model. So each year we select five students and the cohort model is intentional. We want to bring in a small number so we can actually make sure that we're effective in what we're doing. So when we bring in the five, again, we work with them. We set it up where they can live together in housing and also I set up their schedules where all of them take their classes together or as many classes together as possible. So, again, they're going to matriculate through the program together and that way they can be that support system for them.

At the end of their first year in the program we require that they go to Clemson for the summer for the Clemson internship. Again, we want them to have that experience where initially so they can really get a sense of what the program is about and spend time with graduates of the program and also the MISTER's from around the country so they can get that sense. After that initial summer we set it up where they get a choice now. So they can either go to Clemson or they can stay here in the state of Mississippi and we'll set them up with their own internship. So we've had MISTER's that have served at, in Cohort 1 they've done both. They've been to Clemson; they've stayed here in Jackson, Mississippi. Cohort 2, which is our sophomores right now, they've been to Clemson and then Cohort 3, which are our freshmen this year, they will be required to go to Clemson.

Here we want to basically do the same thing. Our goal is that, yes, they have to put those four years in a Mississippi classroom. Yes, we want to keep them around. We want them to have the skillset to either stay in the classroom, become consultants, become administrators but stay in the field of education and hopefully stay here in the state of Mississippi so we can make a difference in our community right here. So, yes, teaching is at the center and the core of what we do and we want them to be able to advocate for the children. We're talking about minorities, male or female. We want them to be able to advocate for whomever ends up in their classrooms.

M: Oh, I'm expecting them to be great teachers. I see a lot of potential. The good thing about the program is again the way it's structured. They get a lot of early field experiences. So by the time they begin their sophomore year they probably spend as much time in the field as our juniors here going through the traditional program. During the summers they spend probably 2 ½ months of full days in the classroom. It's not observation type work. They're either co-teaching or some of those in the upper class are teaching the classrooms themselves. So they're getting a ton of experience early on in the classroom.

Those classes, the teacher education classes were kind of mandatory. They worked all day and whatever and it was kind of like really pulling teeth to get them to kind of get through this. In my own classes like the drug and alcohol counseling I really run everybody through treatment and basically they're the counselor and they're a client. So they pair up. So it's more like a hands on and it's a cohort group because I have to teach everything one year. So whenever I'm teaching that year I have them all for every class and they go through it. Then the next year it's the same. They tend to help each other and work that way. So that's a good tool. We thought about cohort because the original teacher ed all those teachers are not retired or gone or whatever. They had a cohort group that they trained several teachers years ago. I think Helen might be one of them. I don't know if you're going to meet her or not. Helen Parker?

I'm kind of teaching a new curriculum. We have the rural health certificate that's going to be geared towards Natives. The applied psych part of it I'm going to do like mindfulness training. We have a facilitator training class that's basically to teach peer counseling. We have three Native classes that were developed by actually she got a lot from Turtle Mountain for them to expand their teacher ed and do teacher ed and early childhood. So then there's three classes on kind of healing like how do you be Native. What does it mean? Some of them are really white, let's face it. The genocide is probably half way alive and well. Their spirits are not, they're gone, they've lost that because of the genocide. So it's up to them to bring it back and then they can decide whether they really want to be Native or white. But it's okay for them. The ones that make it learn like I could be Native in my own home and Native in my heart, Native in my spirit but I can utilize the Western money or the Western ways but they have to know that that's separate. It's just a kinder genocide really when they give handouts or all of this kind of stuff. It's just a simpler, kinder type of genocide. It's not really okay who are you, what do you stand for, how do you?

So we're trying to have this Native, rural Native degree as part of that kind of looking at the genocide, the trauma. I work with that age, the adverse childhood experience and we're trying to research some of that. Then research some of these classes this summer to see if that does heal. So really I'm more interested in healing and whether they know stuff. I can heal them they can go and do what they need to do. Of course I teach human services so I have the luxury of not being able to teach more from that perspective than okay here's this academic nose to the grindstone, here is what is expected of you in a European way. They joke about it. I'm kind of an odd teacher or whatever but that's really kind of what we're trying to do.

F: Like becoming a whole person. They call them the full body, basically they heal but that would be in your mind, your body, your spirit and your emotions are whole and you're walking in them. Then you can, whatever life, whatever you want to do but you're balanced. The Native people really originally and they've lost a lot of it. That's why I think they were feared because they interacted with nature as part of the whole. So they could do things. They worked with their mind. Actually we just had a lecture from Joseph -0:17:33- he's on a sabbatical at Bozeman and he came up and we had this research conference. Natives, the original natives were rather violet culture. They counted coup but they used that strength, that mastery, that mastery of more, that mastery of life and to utilize their mind and strength and all of their ceremonies and life with that mastery, that sense of whatever.

Then at the end of the day, at the end of that time you missed say 12 or 50 or whatever and then it tells you what they are, what the answers are. So that tells you right away, you know what, I'm having problems with geometry. So that means I need to work on my geometry. I need to get an eighth grade book. I tell them if you get an eighth grade book, textbook, math, reading, whatever, you get an eighth grade book you should be able to pass the test.

It definitely is. It's really interesting to think about. My mom is nearly illiterate. She has a little ability with reading and writing but was not, she told us stories. She couldn't read necessarily to us that much but she told us stories. Then she got me in Head Start. That really changes things. I'm just thinking of how that period from one to five is just and we know now with all the research that's going on that that period is really important. So how do you stop that cycle? I hope they're going to get compulsory kindergarten.

hen I got the creative award I selected a group of students. I selected them and I said okay I didn't have any control over them. I just had them come to the lab and do the interactive tests. I also had the workshops and had some people come in and said oh this is working. So I said well I think this should become part of a class. But I think it should become part of a class in addition to a class. So this is a three hour class and taking one of the class periods. It has to be a standalone lab. It has to be a lab where these students attend the class for two days, Monday and Wednesday, and then they should go to the lab.

The students, there is a variety of students. We get the range of students that are fresh out of high school and I've even had some students into their, gee, I had one student that was 68 at one time. So there's a range of age. The majority of them are concerned about their culture.

: It's been interesting. It's been a little bit of a challenge being the fact that this is the first time we've done something like this. We were trying to figure out okay if I have four credit class how many hours is that at a semester level. That was kind of one of the challenges. M: Their level is a little weak here. I think the majority of the students when they test they test into either basic math or beginning algebra. For me it's all about the challenges. When I was teaching at Havre there was no challenge there. You showed up to work, you did your job, you're done. Out here you get such a variety of students out there and you're trying to teach to each one of them and that's the reward I get is the challenges. I would never make it at a desk job where all you have to do is just write things down and turn it in. I need something that will stick with me just a little bit. That's why I stay here.

It's encouragement is what it is, what it amounts to. It doesn't necessarily mean I'm just saying gold star. It's, yes, you got right, absolutely. Encouragement is the idea of that one. M: An example of that, with the class I was teaching for SKC we did a couple of, we did like Rocky Boy around pow wow circuit type deal. I make sure that we cover everything on it before the test happens. You'll see this a lot like with my beginning algebra students. Every day it's a fraction type thing because that's where they're weakest at. We've got some fractions that we have to deal with. It's just exposure, exposure, exposure. Then one of the biggest things that helps out with them is I'll give them a review sheet before, a day or two before the test. It's up to them to do it. If they have question they can ask me about it and then if they want to they can use that review sheet on the test. That seems to help a little bit. There are some students that will take advantage of it. A lot of them won't.

I think our NMSU classes have been really, really good at that. I think just the whole bilingual program has helped us realize that there is those issues. We see it in our community and there are children who feel left out and who feel lower than other students because of their language. NMSU has really helped me just gain a wider view and new ways and strategies in how we can promote that equity and help them.

So they go over them and he's really good at explaining and he goes all about bringing real life experiences. He goes to the store. He makes up stories. I think that's wonderful. He makes up stories about him going to Home Depot or Lowes and buying materials to build a home for his dog. So they're learning on perimeter and area and how much do I have to, how much fence do I have to buy in order to give him enough room. F: It's third grade. So we get to switch. One week is we get the Spanish. The students are mixed in general but where the students go one week in Spanish and one week in English and I'm always in the Spanish. I see a lot of the English dominant students. So we kind of like translate and we use a lot of English more with them than with the Spanish. That's where it differs.

My greatest concern right now would be just being effective as a teacher to help the students with all the tests and prepare them because they are hard. Right now I am in third grade so it's their first year taking the test. So I see my teacher working very hard to help them and kind of guide them. So I think that would be my issue of concern how to help them.

Yes, and I think that's very important. We had an issue where we were preparing our science lesson and so we were getting our lesson from the book, from the science book that they're doing. We turned it in and our feedback that our teacher, our NMSU teacher told us this lesson is under grade level. It's for a second grade when you're doing third. The lesson was on matter and the properties of matter, just the properties in general like hardness and shape. So she told us that it was below grade level that by that age they should be doing solids, liquids and gases and separating mixtures and all that. We go well this is what the book said. She asked me if I could take a picture of the book and send it to her. She told us that she hadn't realized that the curriculum had changed. The curriculum doesn't meet or it does in a way but it's not very specific. So she came down here when she was here and she took a look at the book and she said yes that's right. The centers don't really match up to the curriculum because there has been a new curriculum.

F: Just everything, just being in the class and listening to the children respond. It comes from them, to talking to parents. I was able to, my practicum teacher invited me to parent teacher conferences so I was there for a couple of conferences and just getting the experience of how a teacher communicates with the parent and tells them you know what your child is so, or you know what your child is doing very well but you need to still help her. So that was very important. He asked me if I could jump in a little bit with one of the conferences. He asked me well what would you say, just me and him before the parent could come in, would you say. I was describing the child and I was telling him that she's very communicative. She's always talking and whispering. He's like okay wait, wait, wait. Stop, stop, stop. So I'm the parent and you're telling me that my child is always talking. How do you think the parent is going to take that? Just being there and talking to the teacher helps us realize be careful with what you're saying.

I started off in -0:02:40- community college for my first two years and that was great. I really enjoyed the small classes and the teachers were great. I had a lot of help from them.
