The thing that's most challenge with the Call Me MISTER program would probably be just really kind of serving as a counselor for 15, we're talking about 15, young black men ranging from 18 to 21 years of age. So any time you're dealing with a group of young people at that age you're going to have some unique situations that come up. So my challenge is day in and day out just really trying to maintain contact with them and make sure that they're doing the things that they're supposed to do and that they're making good decisions. When they have problems or issues that come up they usually show up at my door to talk to me. It's basically trying to balance that.

Then the other thing would be finance. Most people think working with this program we say we pay full tuition. They think that everything is covered. That makes it all right for the young men that they don't have any financial difficulties or problems. But what we find out is that's not the case with the program. So, yes, we pay for full tuition and we pay for books but we don't cover room and board. Really that's one of the things that I didn't really understand because room and board is central to the program. If you're trying to have people live together and go through classes together I would think that room and board would be one of the main things that you provided for because, again, that's at the heart of the program. So they have some financial challenges with that and it's not as much for the state people as it is for the out of state people because they pay the extra probably close to $10,000 a year just for out of state fees

we encourage the research process greatly. Each year we take a cohort and we apply for the Center for Undergraduate Research mini grant. They give us about $5,000 to support travel to different conferences. So each year I work with a different cohort. So Cohort 1 presented at the NAAS Conference down in Baton Rouge last year. This year I took Cohort 2, well it was mostly Cohort 2. There were a couple from Cohort 1. We went down there and presented again. This year what I have students to do was actually interview African American male teachers in local elementary schools. So, again, they can get a sense of what they were getting into and then they presented on their research. So each year we're going to make sure that each of the cohorts get that experience as an undergraduate researching.

we mentor young men throughout the program. We get them a lot of early experiences in the field working and teaching with children and then we provide them with support throughout the program in order to make sure that they're successful. So that's the general model that all of us follow.

they allow us the freedom to decide exactly how we're going to implement that and then they provide us with whatever support that we needs. So here at Jackson State basically what we do, again, we have it set up where the initial year that they come in we work with the students. Again, we get them set up with mentors out in the schools. We also provide them with experiences to serve and working with young kids along with taking their courses. We utilize the cohort model. So each year we select five students and the cohort model is intentional. We want to bring in a small number so we can actually make sure that we're effective in what we're doing. So when we bring in the five, again, we work with them. We set it up where they can live together in housing and also I set up their schedules where all of them take their classes together or as many classes together as possible. So, again, they're going to matriculate through the program together and that way they can be that support system for them.

At the end of their first year in the program we require that they go to Clemson for the summer for the Clemson internship. Again, we want them to have that experience where initially so they can really get a sense of what the program is about and spend time with graduates of the program and also the MISTER's from around the country so they can get that sense. After that initial summer we set it up where they get a choice now. So they can either go to Clemson or they can stay here in the state of Mississippi and we'll set them up with their own internship. So we've had MISTER's that have served at, in Cohort 1 they've done both. They've been to Clemson; they've stayed here in Jackson, Mississippi. Cohort 2, which is our sophomores right now, they've been to Clemson and then Cohort 3, which are our freshmen this year, they will be required to go to Clemson.

we encourage the research process greatly. Each year we take a cohort and we apply for the Center for Undergraduate Research mini grant. They give us about $5,000 to support travel to different conferences. So each year I work with a different cohort. So Cohort 1 presented at the NAAS Conference down in Baton Rouge last year. This year I took Cohort 2, well it was mostly Cohort 2. There were a couple from Cohort 1. We went down there and presented again. This year what I have students to do was actually interview African American male teachers in local elementary schools. So, again, they can get a sense of what they were getting into and then they presented on their research. So each year we're going to make sure that each of the cohorts get that experience as an undergraduate researching.

I would like the MISTER's to basically say that, look, they realize that they have a responsibility and their responsibility is not just to themselves but it's to their brothers that are going through the Call Me MISTER program and also to their community. They have responsibility to give back and make their community better when they go through the program. That's number one for me and it is one that I kind of harp on because I think it's one that we're struggling with a little bit. We see growth but it's one of the things that I would like to see us improve on a little bit more is students not just having personal responsibility but taking responsibility for their cohort member or taking responsibility for the other MISTER's. So if you see someone in need of help, if someone is struggling in math and you know you're good in math why aren't you helping them. Why do they have to come to me or why do I have to recommend that you go help your friend out because you all are living together. You all see each other more than I do. So it's something that I would like for them to get to the point where it comes really naturally. So that's one of the basic tenets.

ambassadorship. So we want them to really be able to get out and tell their stories. These guys have really unique stories. Again like I said, we have MISTER's that came in on academic probation. We have MISTER's that came in at the top of their class and they're all kind of going through this experience together.

Our goal is that, yes, they have to put those four years in a Mississippi classroom. Yes, we want to keep them around. We want them to have the skillset to either stay in the classroom, become consultants, become administrators but stay in the field of education and hopefully stay here in the state of Mississippi so we can make a difference in our community right here. So, yes, teaching is at the center and the core of what we do and we want them to be able to advocate for the children. We're talking about minorities, male or female. We want them to be able to advocate for whomever ends up in their classrooms.

Yes, but again so we want them to know whether or not their brothers are struggling so again they can be there to help them or if they're not going to class they need to make sure that they're getting there. That's the whole idea of them being in a cohort and going through it together. So, yes, it's transparent. This year we just implemented an awards process. So we're giving them awards for highest GPA this year. We have like an athletic competition award so between the cohorts. So which cohort wins the most basketball games, shoots the best, at archery, those type things. We also have like an attendance award for events and then we're going to do like one overall called Call Me MISTER or something like this who is really exemplifying the qualities of a MISTER. So again that's something that they get really excited about and again the whole transparency of putting everything on the board kind of helps out with that process.

The other thing, again, is ambassadorship. So we want them to really be able to get out and tell their stories. These guys have really unique stories. Again like I said, we have MISTER's that came in on academic probation. We have MISTER's that came in at the top of their class and they're all kind of going through this experience together. So, again, ambassadorship.

One of the things that I've been thinking about adding a little component for next year is actually having them get involved a little bit in the political process. We focus in on teaching and service. We focus in on research but up to this point we've pretty much ignored the political process. I think this is an ideal time particularly in the state of Mississippi for them to kind of get a feel for that. So, again, we just want them to have a lot of tools to be able to draw from when they go into the classroom. So whichever route they choose to take they will be equipped to handle it.

The other thing, again, is ambassadorship. So we want them to really be able to get out and tell their stories. These guys have really unique stories. Again like I said, we have MISTER's that came in on academic probation. We have MISTER's that came in at the top of their class and they're all kind of going through this experience together. So, again, ambassadorship.

We have one young man that actually came to Jackson State and the only reason he came here was to play in the Sonic Boom. So the band attracted him. His original plan was to come here and stay a year and play in the Boom and then I guess he was going to leave, I don't know, and go back to his home state. But the Call Me MISTER program was what changed that for him, getting involved with this now and he's been here three years and he really wants to be a teacher after being involved in this program. Initially that was a student that we were going to lose just because he didn't really think he could afford to stay here, for one, and it was never in his long range plan to graduate from this university. I see with that young man we've already made a difference in that aspect.

Our goal is that, yes, they have to put those four years in a Mississippi classroom. Yes, we want to keep them around. We want them to have the skillset to either stay in the classroom, become consultants, become administrators but stay in the field of education and hopefully stay here in the state of Mississippi so we can make a difference in our community right here. So, yes, teaching is at the center and the core of what we do and we want them to be able to advocate for the children. We're talking about minorities, male or female. We want them to be able to advocate for whomever ends up in their classrooms.

Another thing that we do, I think this one is kind of unique to our program, is we encourage the research process greatly. Each year we take a cohort and we apply for the Center for Undergraduate Research mini grant. They give us about $5,000 to support travel to different conferences. So each year I work with a different cohort. So Cohort 1 presented at the NAAS Conference down in Baton Rouge last year. This year I took Cohort 2, well it was mostly Cohort 2. There were a couple from Cohort 1. We went down there and presented again. This year what I have students to do was actually interview African American male teachers in local elementary schools. So, again, they can get a sense of what they were getting into and then they presented on their research. So each year we're going to make sure that each of the cohorts get that experience as an undergraduate researching.

Another thing that we do is, again, we make sure that our MISTER's get a lot of exposure. So we want them to have a lot of opportunities talking to different people, doing interviews and things like this but also public figures. Again, we want them to not just go into the classroom to be qualified teachers but we want them to be able to be leaders in their community. So a lot of what we do is try to give them as many experiences as possible so that they can excel at what they do. So that's pretty much the general setup for here.

My whole way of working with students is I'll talk to you but you're going to ultimately make the decision because I want you to be able to make decisions. If you're going to work with young children, if you're going to help them in the future you need to be able to recognize this process to know what it's like and help them make decisions without handicapping them by telling them what to do every time.

I'm expecting them to be great teachers. I see a lot of potential. The good thing about the program is again the way it's structured. They get a lot of early field experiences. So by the time they begin their sophomore year they probably spend as much time in the field as our juniors here going through the traditional program. During the summers they spend probably 2 ½ months of full days in the classroom. It's not observation type work. They're either co-teaching or some of those in the upper class are teaching the classrooms themselves. So they're getting a ton of experience early on in the classroom.

at the end of their freshman year they're required to go to Clemson and do that internship. So we had talked to all of them and gotten them ready. I sent out a text a couple of days before just telling everybody make sure that you had everything packed up and ready to go. He never replied back to me. He wanted to go to a Lil Boosie concert that summer and it was basically during the concert was going to take place during the time of the internship. We told him that there's no way for him to get back for the concert. So in his mind he wasn't going to go. So now we're looking at the mentality at that point in time. The day before I hadn't heard from him. I just called him and invited him out for lunch. We went out and got some barbeque and just sat down and talked. Just from our conversation, because I had an idea that he hadn't planned on going. He just wasn't going to say anything and was going to miss the van or whatever. But from that conversation he decided to go up there and he really enjoyed the experience and it changed. When he came back to begin that fall you could see the whole change in his mentality and he has become one of the leaders in the program now. In terms of whatever we do he's one of the first to volunteer for it, one of the first ones to step out front in what it is they're trying to do. So little successes like that is what helps keep all of us going that work with the program when we can see the growth in the students that we're working with.

just from working with them and what I've found is that some of our most intelligent kids didn't do well in high school. So it's kind of interesting and it may or may not translate over into college. So we've had some that didn't do well in high school, didn't score well on ACT, come into college and are doing great. Then we've had vice versa where some of them had high ACT scores, I mean we don't have any with a high ACT that are failing or anything but they did come in at the level that we expected. So we're really getting a mix range at least from among the MISTER's. I think what partially contributes to that is just the amount of stuff that they're engaged in and involved in. So they're juggling a lot of different things, not just coursework. The things that we're asking them to do and then they're getting all of this extra attention for being a part of this program and then all of their personal interests that they want to do some of everything at college. One of the things that I see them struggling with the most is just really trying to figure out how do we juggle all of these things that we want to do and how do we make decisions that are going to be best for us.

My whole way of working with students is I'll talk to you but you're going to ultimately make the decision because I want you to be able to make decisions. If you're going to work with young children, if you're going to help them in the future you need to be able to recognize this process to know what it's like and help them make decisions without handicapping them by telling them what to do every time.

joke about it sometimes. Sometimes they get a little more attention than my nine year old does, at least academically. So, yes, I'm very involved with what they do. They can change the whole perspective on my day. When they're doing well that can make my day go very, very well. I can be having a great day and then one of them walks in my office and just messes it all up. So, again, I do kind of see myself as a father figure and again what I want to do is just help them make good decisions so that they can be the best that they can be in what they're doing.

with all that my philosophy is I'm not here to get you out of trouble. I'm here to help you make good decisions. So whatever it is that you have to deal with I'm here to talk to you about it and help, try to help lead you to the responsible decision. But again at the end of the day you're a grownup and it's your decision to make and you're going to determine how you handle it. But again I'm going to advise you but it's your decision ultimately.

There are not, to my knowledge, very many minorities in the science ed arena. In fact, I only know of one or two other people with my background. That's pretty much why we came here. It's a Hispanic serving institution, which was something really interesting to me that I wanted to serve the community in that way back in the Southwest.

Coming from K State which is a predominately white institution where we had 23,000 students but only I think less than 5% were of minority. When I first went to K State we only had about 500 Latino students. When I left we had over 1,200. So they're doing much better. But coming here I'm seeing we're 44% Latino and that was exciting to me. I don't see that reflected in our teacher ed program, which is a concern. We're trying to recruit more of our Latino students into the program especially bilingual. We don't have as many bilingual students as we would like.

Yeah, it's across the board. A lot of our students are in the criminal justice program, which is an excellent program here at New Mexico State. Then we have students that are in business. So our Latino students tend to gravitate towards those social services rather than education. So it was something that I thought was really interesting when I first came. I was thinking, I was expecting to see a lot more Latino students in our classrooms but we're not seeing the numbers that I would have expected. It varies from one semester to the other. Sometimes we'll have more bilingual students and again this is New Mexico. It's a unique state in that they have a bilingual constitution. So in the constitution we're obligated to offer bilingual services to all of our students whether they be Native American with the Pueblo languages or here with the Spanish language. So that's unique. I don't know that a lot of our students realize that when they come into the program.

F: Yes, when the constitution was originally written that was always part of the constitution. Like I said, New Mexico is a unique state in that a lot of the Chicanos and a lot of the Spanish that came here early on they made sure that their rights were preserved whereas when you go over to Texas it's very different or even Arizona. New Mexico is unique in that way.

ve had some students say that they had such a poor experience that they want it to be different and so that's why they're in. I've had several students who told me about that but not saying that they didn't want to be teachers because they had such a poor experience.

We haven't done that in our methods courses. That's something that we talk about. I do a lesson on using technology in the classroom and understanding what that means for our young people. The teachers, the classroom teachers themselves they take them through practice tests. PARCC offers, the state offers them a chance to practice but they also do that because of the infrastructure we want to make sure. I think the first year they tried it they crashed all over the state. Some districts are very rural. They don't have access and the same broad bandwidth is very concerning. Then a lot of them had older computers and all those kinds of things that they're trying to mitigate at this point.

Yeah, it's across the board. A lot of our students are in the criminal justice program, which is an excellent program here at New Mexico State. Then we have students that are in business. So our Latino students tend to gravitate towards those social services rather than education. So it was something that I thought was really interesting when I first came. So that's unique. I don't know that a lot of our students realize that when they come into the program.

As I mentioned before, we have two semesters of Block before the students student teach. The On-Site Block, which is what we're talking about here, the students spend anywhere from 120 to 150 hours a semester in the classroom with the teacher. Then they have seminar courses which are content courses outside of that. So our students are with the teachers in the classroom with the students working every day Monday through Thursday pretty much 7:30 in the morning until 11:00 in the morning. So they get about 3 ½ hours a day. Then our seminar is on Wednesdays so they cut short in the classroom and they come in and learn about the methods courses. So we do a lot of observations. I teach the science methods course so my students have to plan lessons for science and then I watch them. I observe them teach and go through the science lessons.

My background comes from K State and we actually had an, ours wasn't on-site but I actually got to, we had a practicum piece that was separate from our methods courses. I was in charge of the practicum as well as my methods course that I taught which was science methods. So I learned a lot about how lesson planning works and those kinds of things because they have a really strong PDS program there and I learned from my mentor. So when I came here I kind of brought a lot of that with me. So I do a lot of lesson planning development within my seminar course. So not only are they learning the science methods they're learning how that applies in practice with their lesson plans. Then we do observe them in the classroom as much as we can.

we have an integrated model so the three professors and I that we all teach the four courses kind of together. We have a Special Education person that does the Special Ed piece and then we have Dr. Juan Freire. He does the early childhood and the reading and then I'm doing the science methods and we try to integrate as much as we can. So every other week or every third week one of us is taking the lead in the seminar course. So, yes, we teach the seminar course at the site. So that's in the spring and we're at North Valley where you were meeting our students. In the fall we're here in Las Cruces. So we alternate the Block. We have two Blocks going concurrently in any given semester. So there's Block B right now is over at Central Elementary. I think you met Violet Henderson earlier today. So she's teaching the reading and the literacy courses over there at that Block and I'm over at North Valley. Then in the fall I'll go to Central and they'll go to North Valley. We kind of switch it out.

We also have an evening Block for those students that can't come and be in the on-site because it's a really large time commitment to be in the on-site program. We have an evening Block. In the spring we teach what's called I-TV which is interactive television because we have three satellite schools in the state that are a part of NMSU but they're in Alamogordo, which is about an hour and fifteen minutes away, Carlsbad, which is about three hours away and Grants, which is four hours away. So they see me on a TV monitor, me and the other instructors teaching the Block. So they take their courses that way. Then we have a representative there that places them in the schools. But even still the evening Block the requirement, the hours are much less than they are for on-site Blocks. So they only, I think they get anywhere from 37 to 40 something hours as semester. So they don't get as much time but a lot of those are some of our more nontraditional students. They have families that they can't, or they have jobs that they really can't be in the school that long. We try to accommodate those students as well. My expectations for them are pretty similar. They still have to do a lesson planning, they still have to do the teaching. I don't get to observe them because their schedules are all over the place but we do have people, the ones that are here in Las Cruces we have people that go out and observe them teach in the classrooms and work with the classroom teachers.

I think our strength is the time that the students get in the classroom, that they actually get to work with practicing teachers and they get to see, especially for that management piece that a lot of the principals say that kids need to know how to manage the classroom, their students do. Unless you're in a classroom, I can assign a textbook and have them read about it and have them do case studies all day long but until they have to actually manage children then they don't have the same, you can't really get that experience.

I was observing one of my students today and she was teaching a sixth grade science lesson. So after about probably about 30 minutes or so and the activity she started losing them. So knowing how to either bring them back or make sure that they stay on task with what they're doing is a challenge. So that's something that they have to learn and we have to try to show them how do to do that. We try to do that when we walk in and take over the classroom sometimes if we have to. Then the teacher is also, they all have their own strategies and what works for them. The other thing, the other good thing is they get to work with different teachers.

In Block A, in the first Block the faculty, either me or whoever I'm working with, we will meet the students the first day. We get their names and a lot of times we'll ask them if they're bilingual TESOL. We'll need to know that because we try to place those in those classroom, in the dual language classrooms. We get their language skills and whether or not they're comfortable speaking Spanish or what level and where they are. Then we will place them because at this point I've been in the classroom, I've been with the schools three years so I know the teachers fairly well. So I kind of try to but we're still kind of hit and miss sometimes because we don't know the students that well. In Block B, the second block, I give recommendations to the faculty for that block which students might work with which teacher. So then they usually go with my recommendations. Sometimes they have to move them around but that's how we do it. We just personally do that. We place them ourselves.

For me whenever they teach a lesson that we observe they have a post lesson reflection that they have to do. They do that for me and I know they do that for Dr. -0:21:32- and I think Dr. -0:21:33- also requires that. So for every lesson they teach they have to do a reflection. Then they also do what we call Praxis journals.

combined syllabus. So the three of us get together and work on the syllabus but it has a description of the Praxis journal. So every week they have one due whether it's for me, Dr. -0:21:58- whoever is assigned for that week. Then that's actually where they get a chance to, we may give them an article to read and say okay so now think about your classroom from this week. What kinds of things have you observed in your classroom that might align with this or that you might use some of these activities in. So, yes, so they have to do that every week. That's part of, that's actually part of our program is to be responsive and reflective.

Before we had to leave for the whole testing window which they were out for a month last year. But this year what she allowed them to do is if their classroom is testing then they got to go and observe in another classroom. So some of our Special Education students that are majoring or focusing on that they got to go observe in a Special Ed classroom and got to talk with those teachers, with the counselors and those types of things. But we do address it. I don't say that because it does impact the students when they're in their testing window. What I do tell them is that it's something that's necessary, it's something we have to be aware of. So the methods that we're trying to teach you or they're good teaching methods and hopefully you'll be able to institute some of those when you go into the classroom and get your students ready for the tests rather than teaching to the tests.

F: What I've done myself is I've actually gone into classes. I have some colleagues in the Spanish department. All of our students have to take a language. They also have a language requirement. So he let me come into his classroom and kind of talk about becoming a teacher and what they can do because a lot of them are freshmen and sophomores. We also have, of course, our Intro to Education program that we do and so our students come in to explore education to see if that's what they want to do.

F: Yes, it's a one hour course and it's Explorations in Education. Then we also have every year they have what's called the Aggie Experience. So the students that are interested in coming to NMSU will come onto campus, just campus visits and those kinds of things. So we usually send a representative from the College of Ed to go and talk about education and meet with them if the students are interested in education.

F: It was really publicized in the state. We just have gone, we've been going through the round of state testing starting in March. So they have the testing window that's a month and a half long. It depends on, they start testing in third grade and they test through high school. It's a high stakes because our students that are in high school if they don't pass they don't graduate. So now their scores are also counting against or the teacher evaluations. Part of their evaluation is based on student test scores.

They have a basic skills test that they have to pass in order to enter the program. So even if they're majoring in education they're not a part of the TEP program, which is our Teacher Education Program, until they've met the GPA requirement and all the prerequisites and they've passed the basic skills tests. So once they pass basic skills then they have to do professional exams. This is usually before they student teach. They also have to have their content. So if they're elementary then they have to pass their elementary content exam through the state. So they have to pass that and their professional exam before they student teach. When they student teach the only other exam that they have to pass, and this is new for New Mexico, is a reading exam. So they have to pass the reading exam that's given through the state in order to be certified.

we've had good success rates for, again, because our students have to have a certain GPA coming in then they're already a certain kind of student. So for the most part they don't struggle. I think we had an 80% passing rate on the basic skills and about that for the profession content. The reading test, again, it's new. It's only been in existence I think two years. So we're still gathering data on pass rates for that particular test.

Before we had to leave for the whole testing window which they were out for a month last year. But this year what she allowed them to do is if their classroom is testing then they got to go and observe in another classroom. So some of our Special Education students that are majoring or focusing on that they got to go observe in a Special Ed classroom and got to talk with those teachers, with the counselors and those types of things. But we do address it. I don't say that because it does impact the students when they're in their testing window. What I do tell them is that it's something that's necessary, it's something we have to be aware of. So the methods that we're trying to teach you or they're good teaching methods and hopefully you'll be able to institute some of those when you go into the classroom and get your students ready for the tests rather than teaching to the tests.

A lot of the teachers that I work with some of them they'll take time out and go over practice tests and that kind of thing but a lot of them really try to meet the standards. Here in the state of New Mexico the Common Core State Standards have been in effect this is the third year. The first year that I came here they were required at that point to start using the standards. This is the first year that they were actually tested, so to speak, through the PARCC system. So that's why it's been kind of up in the air. We had protests from our high school students at the beginning of the testing window. It's been, a lot of my students know what's going on and a lot of the kids coming out of high school obviously know what's going on. So that's how they know about it.

We haven't done that in our methods courses. That's something that we talk about. I do a lesson on using technology in the classroom and understanding what that means for our young people. The teachers, the classroom teachers themselves they take them through practice tests. PARCC offers, the state offers them a chance to practice but they also do that because of the infrastructure we want to make sure. I think the first year they tried it they crashed all over the state. Some districts are very rural. They don't have access and the same broad bandwidth is very concerning. Then a lot of them had older computers and all those kinds of things that they're trying to mitigate at this point.

As I mentioned before, we have two semesters of Block before the students student teach. The On-Site Block, which is what we're talking about here, the students spend anywhere from 120 to 150 hours a semester in the classroom with the teacher. Then they have seminar courses which are content courses outside of that. So our students are with the teachers in the classroom with the students working every day Monday through Thursday pretty much 7:30 in the morning until 11:00 in the morning. So they get about 3 ½ hours a day. Then our seminar is on Wednesdays so they cut short in the classroom and they come in and learn about the methods courses. So we do a lot of observations. I teach the science methods course so my students have to plan lessons for science and then I watch them. I observe them teach and go through the science lessons.

I think our strength is the time that the students get in the classroom, that they actually get to work with practicing teachers and they get to see, especially for that management piece that a lot of the principals say that kids need to know how to manage the classroom, their students do. Unless you're in a classroom, I can assign a textbook and have them read about it and have them do case studies all day long but until they have to actually manage children then they don't have the same, you can't really get that experience.

It's pretty loose. It's pretty laid back. People get to know each other and we get a lot of help from the staff and students help each other. We've got tutoring. It's more or less pretty laid back. I guess it's not like where you get lost with 270 students in a class.
They try. There's a lot of poverty up here. This is one of their ways out. It's a stepping stone I always call it, a stepping stone to higher ed and get on to a four year college. I

Monday drum is very, very, very good. Our students they should have Monday drum, Tuesday drum, Wednesday drum, every day really. You can go by the culture then you're using their language and they're singing their songs, they're learning. They're sitting there respectfully and plus they get to eat. A lot of them come to school to eat because like I said we have a lot of poverty up here. We see a lot of hungry students. We have the learning center where they provide food. The lady she'll go once a week and buy some sandwich stuff or chips, some drinks. They're there and they'll eat. It's free food. So I see it. You even see that in Boys and Girls Club when they used to have one when it was open. They'd feed the students right after school and stuff. They'd go over there because they knew they were going to get something to eat.

Our culture is like you're going to tease somebody. You make them laugh and they'll wonder if you're joking or not. You make them feel comfortable. That's how I am anyway. That's about how just about everybody is around here. There's not too much uppity up or real serious people that are going to look down on you. They're going to make you feel comfortable just being here.

I've got a lot of students that didn't finish so I had to report them and they owe all this money because they signed that payback agreement. At first I believe in them, I really believe in them when I talk to them and something happens in their life. Maybe they find out teaching is not for them or they move or they get a job or something. I still tell them you've got to pay that money back. It really hasn't been hitting them until like maybe this year because their taxes are getting away and stuff like that.

Getting up in the morning, I guess, is their biggest challenge because really here you shouldn't, there's no reason not to succeed really, I believe anyway, to get your two year. But our college needs to prepare them to get ready for that four year degree and that's what we've been doing with like Salish Kootenai College over there.

That's probably one of the cop outs that they do is they say they don't have a ride or all this stuff but that's wrong because we've got a shuttle now that goes to Havre every day, goes straight to that college. When I was going to Northern I'd get on the highway and I would hitchhike or I'd ride with friends. Then we had another one at Western but that was a little too far.

They're smart. The strengths they have is I've seen a lot of them with determination. Once they leave the reservation and if they go to a different college, like I said, this is just a stepping stone and they're happy if they go to the University of Montana or Montana State or even Northern or a different college, Salish.

: I think they use it for their families. The ones that stick around they save it and they use it for their education. We get quite a few that graduate every year but we get about the same amount that to me anyway that drop out every year because we wait. We wait for first Pell because they pay their bills, their school bills with that first Pell and the second Pell they divide it and we say well we'll see how many come back next week and it's a big drop. A lot of them just don't come back. They'll come back the next semester to start over again.
lot of them come to school to eat because like I said we have a lot of poverty up here. We see a lot of hungry students.

we're supposed to have 18 graduate for a four year period. I got, we had seven graduate already and we've got about eight student teaching right now. f you had two children you're getting $1,500 a month. So a lot of them are on this program for the money and I guess in their own way and now they have to pay it back the ones that did quit.

I went to Stone Child and I graduated from here and I went to Northern because before that I was a tribal judge for 16 years. I learned the law and stuff like that on my own and stuff. So I went back, came here to Stone Child and I went to Northern and graduated and then I started my masters and I started getting burned out working at the same time because I got hired here.

they are really in the same great experience and that sometimes requires a lot of effort from their side because from who we are our students, who the students are, they need to work to help with family. Sometimes they are tired and sometimes they are taking care of daytime. So having the practicum during the day is really difficult but they save money before they take those courses so they can actually do it. So they are that committed, sacrificing a lot of different things to be able to have this experience and be prepared as teachers. We have students that not all of our students are Hispanic necessarily but I think that they are passionate about teaching. If they are not having that experience they will recognize that and they will move to another area if that is what they choose, which is good.

First we talk a lot about what is going on in the classrooms and who are the students that they have. So they somehow are forced to start paying attention to their students as people not as how they are performing in the class. That's one way. Another way is we have a lot of readings about different situations, different I would say social issues that students may have, families may have. So we discuss about that and we try to connect to what is going on in the classroom site and looking at students in that way. As I always say I tell the students that teaching the math is important but being there for the students is more important. We try to connect in that way and I try to do the same with them, with the preservice teachers, so they can somehow connect to how I feel they will be in the classrooms.

So kind of creating that community, kind of talking about that and also talking about me in a way that sometimes we talk about the students having difficulties in their homes and how it's difficult to identify how to help the students being a new teacher. Then I share my experiences when I was a teacher. I was a teacher when I was 17 in Colombia and I was teaching second graders. So I was 17 years old teaching nine years old. So having those experiences and sharing what happened with me at that time and what I learned and what I did that wasn't good and all that that may help them to feel that if we fail it's not because we want to fail but it's because we are learning through that process. So sharing experiences like that and also my mom was a teacher,

As well preparing teachers they need experiences in the classrooms and in the schools. So the blocks are experiences that I feel are awesome in the way that they are in the classroom at least during the math methods courses for one full year. They are in the class and they go to the classrooms two hours per day I think we are going back. We have been changing how many hours.

When I was teaching it was from 7:30 until 10:00 they were in the classroom with the teacher and the students. Sometimes they were allowed to teach some of the classes. After that we go to the seminar which is two hours meeting where we discuss what was going on in the classroom at the same time our content. So they are experiencing. They have a lot of practical experience but at the same time we connect that to the theory when we are in the seminar and we work with them.

I came six years ago and I believe it has been in place like for eight years. So when I moved here they already had that. So what is really amazing is that when they decided that was in Spanish. So our seminars were in Spanish. The students that were a part of the on-site blocks they were bilingual students. So they had the opportunity to receive the seminar or to be there during the seminar time in Spanish. Sometimes in their school they have Spanish days or English days. So they have the flexibility with it. The students start -0:07:03- about their blocks and the experiences that they had. They start asking to be part of that even though they were not fluent in Spanish.

m remember students at the beginning of the semester. They are usually so afraid that they have to be in front of the class the first time and all that. I don't know what else can I say.

I try to do a lot of activities at the same time we are talking about methods, teaching methods. I try to work on the content so making them stronger in that area. They usually complain because they say well, yes, we have these methods, we have all of these different things but it's still in the test they don't have anything like that. They have to answer and know the processes and all of that. We have a lot of discussion in that way but the main idea that I try to leave is that I want them to recognize that if we are teaching in an environment that the students maybe learn, would understand it somewhere in the test that they would have. They may be able to find it but if they are just memorizing the process that is not going to be any help. It's not going to be helpful for the kids. So I try to have them recognizing that different ways to teach will help learning assessments in the way that the state has indicated may not be naturally what they know. The most important part is what they as teaches will see in the classroom.

I am a math educator. I was teaching elementary and secondary math methods courses. Right now I am teaching secondary math methods courses and research courses as well. Probably next semester I will go back to elementary. That's mainly my teaching load.

I was coordinator of the blocks as well as faculty. The interaction includes working with the teachers, the elementary students as well as the preservice teachers. Teaching the secondary math courses but at the same time going out observe them when they are teaching in the classrooms, working with the teachers what they allow them to be teaching and how they can be teaching, organizing the teachers and the principals the math night and math days at the schools, being there with the parents and community.

Caring. It's a person that really cares about their students in different areas not just academic like learning mathematics or being able to answer a test or anything like that. That is one part but in addition to that is who they are, how they can connect, who is the family, how can they get close to you to support you as a human being not just a mind that we look at a lot of numbers and symbols and all that. So that to me is what a teacher, a caring person.

I am from Colombia. When I finished my bachelor degree I decided to continue with just a master's program in mathematics. I left my country and then moved to Puerto Rico and then from there many things happened. I ended up going to Virginia to get my Ph.D. in math education. When I finished this position was open here and I loved the opportunity to be in a Hispanic environment. So I applied and here I am. I have been here for six years.

they try, they go above and beyond what to keep you here, to keep retention, the retention goals. They tried transportation, Monday drum. A Monday drum is when the weekly announcements. You sit down and you get to visit with everybody. Everyone is welcome. They have prayer

we had to complete so many hours in the classroom both here and at Northern. The easy part that I liked was that I got to go in and I got to watch and I didn't have to do discipline. I'm not looking forward to telling them to behave. I get to sit there and I say please listen to her but I don't want to deal with getting upset with them yet but it needs to be done the classroom management.

Another part was having to be, another part that I see myself struggling with is not being able to be their mom, not buying them what they need, not providing new shoes if you notice their shoes are getting worn out or tee shirts. I know schools have a lot of lost and found and you can donate items and they help with that but I'm going to have a really hard time separating the mother in me to the teacher. I'll figure it out because it has to happen. They're kind of like yours because you spend eight hours a day with them, almost eight hours a day and almost everything. So that's going to be the hard part telling them, trying not to be mom and just be their teacher.

So after that ended I was sitting at home and I was thinking about ways that I can still help these kids, help me reach out to these little ones. I was like I'll be a teacher. I love working with them and it was insightful and it was an experience that only you can have with that person, hands on and day to day activities. I would like to instill in them respect and understanding of the bigger world, that there's opportunities for them, start teaching them while they're young. They're building their self-esteem while they're young so when they get older it's older.

I graduated from here but roughly eight to ten years ago with a liberal arts degree. I transferred out and when I transferred out I went to the local Northern University and I didn't make it. I got sick and I failed and so I started working. When I started working or when I failed and what happened is when I got sick and became a diabetic at a young age. I was 23. So 22 and 23 I was a diabetic and it felt like the world came down. So I started all over again.

So after that ended I was sitting at home and I was thinking about ways that I can still help these kids, help me reach out to these little ones. I was like I'll be a teacher. I love working with them and it was insightful and it was an experience that only you can have with that person, hands on and day to day activities. It's wonderful. It is wonderful, because it is a small community. It is a farming community and I love it, because you have really good students. Because of the way they run the system, like I was talking to somebody just this morning. We have block A and block B, and so block A is your first year of getting a whole morning to work within the classroom, and then block B, which is in the fall is the second experience they have, and then after block B they do their student teaching. So each semester you get a different batch of students.

it like 380. About 18 teachers, 18 to 20, depending on, we just move around. F: I think many of them are just wanting to get a career and they have jobs. A lot of them are not only going to school but they work and this is what they're preparing themselves to do. The expectation is for them to get hand on learning in the classroom and just get experience with the students. I guess all of the ones I have mentored, they have two jobs. F: Most of them have been single. I only have mentored a couple that have been married, they're trying to raise a family and go to school so they have to work. But the girl that I have right now, she works in El Paso, she lives in Sandland Park and she goes to MSU, so it's a lot of traveling, and I think she works late in El Paso. But I think a lot of them have to do that. That's normal for them, that's what they're doing. Sometimes when see her, I have some kind of a block when my kids go to Art in the morning, and I see her go looking through her books. I try to let her just get a sense of where she needs to be in her class work, but also I think she needs to do it in the classroom. I allow her some time for her to just get ready, because she's a person just like me. She has a family and she has a different life besides being in the classroom.

We are dealing with a student right now, she has a lot of issues. Sometimes she pulls back and looks and then she goes I don't know what I would have done. I go, you know what? When you are there, you know what to do. You just have to be prepared for a lot. He throws tantrums. He loses it, and I have to call the office for them to get him. We have to take him to the room and we have to take a long walk and take the kids to the bathroom when he has been removed from the classroom and walk back in when he is removed. She learns about that. You do tell them the community. It is a poor community, low socioeconomic issues. One parent, a lot of one parent families at times. The reason they go to Chamborino, -0:13:24.9-, the area they come from is a low socioeconomic area, it is because a lot of them cannot afford housing in the city, in the bigger cities, so they tend to go out of the urban areas to the farming areas where we have more options for them in low rent. Usually the standards are lower too. So, she gets to see that on the students. We do deal with a lot of socioeconomic issues here.

Let me see; the challenges I face. I think the opportunities are great. There are a lot of positions right now for bilingual education, especially within Los Cruces public schools. They are always hiring and trying to recruit a lot of the teachers, especially from this district, that live in the area, and because of their program, their bilingual programs, the opportunities are great. The challenges are that we still, now with the new math program we have a lot, I think a couple of years, you don't find a lot of books. If you go to the book room right now, you have maybe six shelves of English guided reading books that the kids can use. If you go to the book room, it has two shelves of Spanish, so there is a lot of discrepancy between the resources we can use as bilingual teachers and the resources, even though we are a bilingual district, a lot of funding goes into that, we get like 25 percent of what they have. The resources are not there, and we try our hardest to make it. We have all big books that we use for reading in the classroom. A lot of your literacy parts of it, any kind of fairy tale, we have some, but when you come to the sciences, you can use integrated science in social studies into the reading, with reading, there is really nothing, nothing, so the challenge is the resources that we have. We don't have as much resources as we would like. And sometimes even the book that, especially with the new Common Core, a lot of Lucy Culkins is being used. I have to go home and type everything out in Spanish and paste it over the words so they could get the sense of that, and I'm thinking some teachers, how many are spending, I mean, it's a lot of time. I try to do it, especially the main ones. A lot of the resources at work, even to teach with the Common Core, we're not there yet as a bilingual district. It is a lot of hard work, a lot of late days trying to translate a lot of that stuff.

we don't minimize their language. We appreciate their language. This little boy, as once I mentioned, he sits with the table right next to an English Dominant. My educational background? I was born in Mexico, and what I did is, my father being an American citizen, my mother Mexican, we emigrated when I was about 15, and so I finished middle school and high school here and I started college. And then through the process of going to college, I got married a year short of my degree, and then I started a family and what happened is my husband, he's a teacher. We were with DOTS and he was working in Korea and then we went to Germany for quite a while, and so when I was there I finished my education and then I got involved with the Armed Forces, and working for the United States Army, I was training people how to write resumes and stuff like that, and I was working -0:01:29.6- program at the high school, at the middle school. And we came back to the States I started working at White Sands Missile Range. I climbed up the ladder and I became the Chief of Personnel for NAF, Nonappropriated Funds. But then I wasn't happy and I went back into my life and decided when were you happy, and I go okay, when I was teaching, so I went back, within a year got my endorsement in teaching and my Master's and then I started teaching. This is my 12th year of working here.

Being a teacher here, you have to be really, really diverse in your skills. You have to be pretty talented. I was just thinking, teaching in a bilingual classroom, it requires a lot more talent it would seem on the part of the teacher.

I love the model. I love the dual language, and I work with both models, because I was in the migrant program myself. You're in a room until you learn English, and you're mainstreaming, so yeah, you have groups calling you different names because you are in that little room, learning English, and you weren't mainstream, and when you mention you're afraid, because the kids poke fun of your second language, they're the ones you're going to be with in the classroom, so your safe haven actually becomes that room. I think this way you don't have that. There is not that discrimination. There is not that sense of you're lesser of a person because you don't speak the dominant language. I think that is one of the reasons I like this program too, because it is dual language.

I go you may not agree with it but you still have to do it. With the Common Core, you have to do with what Common Core says, and you may not agree with a lot of the stuff, but you have to deal with it.

F: I do a lot of modeling, a lot of them to see how the classroom can run and just give them strategies to use in the classroom. We have a balanced literacy as a vehicle for us to teach reading, writing and I love it. I think when they go other places they may have different programs to run their schools, but I think for them to see how you can use anything in teaching reading You can use whatever programs their school is using and teaching writing, and I think that the purpose for them to model teaching, so they could gather those strategies and take them home, or to school, the next school.

F: A lot of mentoring. They present lessons and you give them a grade on that and how they work in the classroom, and you redirect them if they are doing something that is going wrong, and any time I grade, I give them a grade, the grade that we use, I let them know why are you here and where do you need to be, and what you need to do to get to this point, when you get 4s and other higher numbers in the group.

Another thing that we do, I think this one is kind of unique to our program, is we encourage the research process greatly. Each year we take a cohort and we apply for the Center for Undergraduate Research mini grant. They give us about $5,000 to support travel to different conferences. So each year I work with a different cohort. So Cohort 1 presented at the NAAS Conference down in Baton Rouge last year. This year I took Cohort 2, well it was mostly Cohort 2. There were a couple from Cohort 1. We went down there and presented again. This year what I have students to do was actually interview African American male teachers in local elementary schools. So, again, they can get a sense of what they were getting into and then they presented on their research. So each year we're going to make sure that each of the cohorts get that experience as an undergraduate researching.

we make sure that our MISTER's get a lot of exposure. So we want them to have a lot of opportunities talking to different people, doing interviews and things like this but also public figures. Again, we want them to not just go into the classroom to be qualified teachers but we want them to be able to be leaders in their community. So a lot of what we do is try to give them as many experiences as possible so that they can excel at what they do.

We have one young man that actually came to Jackson State and the only reason he came here was to play in the Sonic Boom. So the band attracted him. His original plan was to come here and stay a year and play in the Boom and then I guess he was going to leave, I don't know, and go back to his home state. But the Call Me MISTER program was what changed that for him, getting involved with this now and he's been here three years and he really wants to be a teacher after being involved in this program. Initially that was a student that we were going to lose just because he didn't really think he could afford to stay here, for one, and it was never in his long range plan to graduate from this university. I see with that young man we've already made a difference in that aspect.

at the end of their freshman year they're required to go to Clemson and do that internship. So we had talked to all of them and gotten them ready. I sent out a text a couple of days before just telling everybody make sure that you had everything packed up and ready to go. He never replied back to me. He wanted to go to a Lil Boosie concert that summer and it was basically during the concert was going to take place during the time of the internship. We told him that there's no way for him to get back for the concert. So in his mind he wasn't going to go. So now we're looking at the mentality at that point in time. The day before I hadn't heard from him. I just called him and invited him out for lunch. We went out and got some barbeque and just sat down and talked. Just from our conversation, because I had an idea that he hadn't planned on going. He just wasn't going to say anything and was going to miss the van or whatever. But from that conversation he decided to go up there and he really enjoyed the experience and it changed. When he came back to begin that fall you could see the whole change in his mentality and he has become one of the leaders in the program now. In terms of whatever we do he's one of the first to volunteer for it, one of the first ones to step out front in what it is they're trying to do. So little successes like that is what helps keep all of us going that work with the program when we can see the growth in the students that we're working with.

I was hooked because it really matched what they were saying about the program really matched my general philosophy of education. They talked about a program that believed in investing in young men that had the desire to teach and helping them be successful and then in return they were going to further their model. They would know how to go out in the schools and work with other young people and invest in them. So that matched up very well with what I believed and I've been working with the program ever since.

we mentor young men throughout the program. We get them a lot of early experiences in the field working and teaching with children and then we provide them with support throughout the program in order to make sure that they're successful. So that's the general model that all of us follow.

they allow us the freedom to decide exactly how we're going to implement that and then they provide us with whatever support that we needs. So here at Jackson State basically what we do, again, we have it set up where the initial year that they come in we work with the students. Again, we get them set up with mentors out in the schools. We also provide them with experiences to serve and working with young kids along with taking their courses. We utilize the cohort model. So each year we select five students and the cohort model is intentional. We want to bring in a small number so we can actually make sure that we're effective in what we're doing. So when we bring in the five, again, we work with them. We set it up where they can live together in housing and also I set up their schedules where all of them take their classes together or as many classes together as possible. So, again, they're going to matriculate through the program together and that way they can be that support system for them.

At the end of their first year in the program we require that they go to Clemson for the summer for the Clemson internship. Again, we want them to have that experience where initially so they can really get a sense of what the program is about and spend time with graduates of the program and also the MISTER's from around the country so they can get that sense. After that initial summer we set it up where they get a choice now. So they can either go to Clemson or they can stay here in the state of Mississippi and we'll set them up with their own internship. So we've had MISTER's that have served at, in Cohort 1 they've done both. They've been to Clemson; they've stayed here in Jackson, Mississippi. Cohort 2, which is our sophomores right now, they've been to Clemson and then Cohort 3, which are our freshmen this year, they will be required to go to Clemson.

They have responsibility to give back and make their community better when they go through the program. That's number one for me and it is one that I kind of harp on because I think it's one that we're struggling with a little bit. We see growth but it's one of the things that I would like to see us improve on a little bit more is students not just having personal responsibility but taking responsibility for their cohort member or taking responsibility for the other MISTER's. So if you see someone in need of help, if someone is struggling in math and you know you're good in math why aren't you helping them. Why do they have to come to me or why do I have to recommend that you go help your friend out because you all are living together. You all see each other more than I do. So it's something that I would like for them to get to the point where it comes really naturally

ambassadorship. So we want them to really be able to get out and tell their stories. These guys have really unique stories. Again like I said, we have MISTER's that came in on academic probation. We have MISTER's that came in at the top of their class and they're all kind of going through this experience together.

Now in terms of how we choose our MISTER's I think that's something that's really, well, it's not unique to just Jackson State but I think the Call Me MISTER program is unique in that it's not a, it's a scholarship program but it's not a traditional scholarship program in that we don't just cater to the highest achieving students. So if you look at our 15 MISTER's at Jackson State we have students that came in on Presidential Scholarship but we also have students that came in taking remedial courses. So what we've done we selected them and we grouped them all together and we're hoping that through that support system with them going through classes as a cohort and with us providing them with extra support that they're going to ensure that all of them can make it.

So basically what we do in terms of recruiting is each year we do a newsletter highlighting the accomplishments that they made the year before. The MISTER's write part of it, I write part of it and we kind of edit it together and send it out. We send it to all of the principals and counsels in the state of Mississippi. Then we also send it out to different organizations, maybe some local churches and so forth. Around this time of March and April our MISTER's start going out and they start talking to the students in local high schools in the Jackson area high schools that may be interested in the program. So some of the visits I set up and some of them they set up themselves and they go out and handle it. So usually what we end up having is three maybe four guys at a high school that have some interest in it and they go and talk to them and tell them about the program and hopefully out of that one or two may apply.

So once that's done by the end of the academic year we want to have that cohort chosen. So we go through an interview process. Initially they apply online. So we go through and we look through the applications online and we get a selected group and contact them for interviews. Our MISTER's participate in the interview process because, again, we want to make sure that they feel like they have ownership in this program because this is their program. So we invite in a couple of local principals, a couple of professors and then the MISTER's are sitting in on the interview panel. We interview students and everyone has an equal vote in who gets elected. Once we've decided we let them know and before the academic year is ended we've selected five. So that way we can go ahead and get finance and everything straightened out so they can enter into the school year early. We also do that because Clemson University has a Call Me MISTER Institute in June and we want those five new ones to be able to attend that three day institute so they can get a sense of what they're coming into for the upcoming year. So that in general is pretty much how our program is set up.

We just ask them to tell us about why they're interested in teaching, some of their experiences working with young children, just those types of things. It's general questions. Just tell me a little bit about yourself and what drives you. So, again, we just really try to get a sense of who they are.

I've always wanted to be a professor at a historically black college. Initially as an undergraduate I went to Tougaloo College, a historically black, small historically black college not far from here. While I was there though I majored in psychology. I decided once I completed that I was going to go into the field of education. I went out to Oklahoma State University. While I was out at Oklahoma State University that's when I was really in the process of grappling with trying to understand my undergraduate experience at Tougaloo College. Again that kind of led me into my dissertation and in the research that I was doing. But with me really trying to make sense of that experience all while I was going through graduate school. Again, it just kind of strengthened my desire to teach at a historically black college.

I was hooked because it really matched what they were saying about the program really matched my general philosophy of education. They talked about a program that believed in investing in young men that had the desire to teach and helping them be successful and then in return they were going to further their model. They would know how to go out in the schools and work with other young people and invest in them. So that matched up very well with what I believed and I've been working with the program ever since.

they allow us the freedom to decide exactly how we're going to implement that and then they provide us with whatever support that we needs. So here at Jackson State basically what we do, again, we have it set up where the initial year that they come in we work with the students. Again, we get them set up with mentors out in the schools. We also provide them with experiences to serve and working with young kids along with taking their courses. We utilize the cohort model. So each year we select five students and the cohort model is intentional. We want to bring in a small number so we can actually make sure that we're effective in what we're doing. So when we bring in the five, again, we work with them. We set it up where they can live together in housing and also I set up their schedules where all of them take their classes together or as many classes together as possible. So, again, they're going to matriculate through the program together and that way they can be that support system for them.

Our goal is that, yes, they have to put those four years in a Mississippi classroom. Yes, we want to keep them around. We want them to have the skillset to either stay in the classroom, become consultants, become administrators but stay in the field of education and hopefully stay here in the state of Mississippi so we can make a difference in our community right here. So, yes, teaching is at the center and the core of what we do and we want them to be able to advocate for the children. We're talking about minorities, male or female. We want them to be able to advocate for whomever ends up in their classrooms.

If you get a 21 or above you're exempt in Mississippi from just the first one, from Praxis I or Case now. We have two that have passed two parts but they didn't pass writing. So they really need to focus in on writing. I would say that's one weakness that we're seeing kind of across the board and not just in Call Me MISTER but in education in general is writing.

A couple of stories I'll share with you all really quick. We have one young man that actually came to Jackson State and the only reason he came here was to play in the Sonic Boom. So the band attracted him. His original plan was to come here and stay a year and play in the Boom and then I guess he was going to leave, I don't know, and go back to his home state. But the Call Me MISTER program was what changed that for him, getting involved with this now and he's been here three years and he really wants to be a teacher after being involved in this program. Initially that was a student that we were going to lose just because he didn't really think he could afford to stay here, for one, and it was never in his long range plan to graduate from this university. I see with that young man we've already made a difference in that aspect.

Weekly basis, some of them are coursework things, other are conflict. We have to decide what do I do. I'm pledging and you all want us to do this and I'm involved in this organization and I need to go here and them making decision, okay, what am I going to do. We have issues, general college student issues where students might get in trouble in the dorm. Somebody brought some alcohol on campus and this is a campus that's closed. So it can be anything. It's just a wide, wide range of things that we have students deal with. Again, with all that my philosophy is I'm not here to get you out of trouble. I'm here to help you make good decisions. So whatever it is that you have to deal with I'm here to talk to you about it and help, try to help lead you to the responsible decision. But again at the end of the day you're a grownup and it's your decision to make and you're going to determine how you handle it. But again I'm going to advise you but it's your decision ultimately.

at the end of their freshman year they're required to go to Clemson and do that internship. So we had talked to all of them and gotten them ready. I sent out a text a couple of days before just telling everybody make sure that you had everything packed up and ready to go. He never replied back to me. He wanted to go to a Lil Boosie concert that summer and it was basically during the concert was going to take place during the time of the internship. We told him that there's no way for him to get back for the concert. So in his mind he wasn't going to go. So now we're looking at the mentality at that point in time. The day before I hadn't heard from him. I just called him and invited him out for lunch. We went out and got some barbeque and just sat down and talked. Just from our conversation, because I had an idea that he hadn't planned on going. He just wasn't going to say anything and was going to miss the van or whatever. But from that conversation he decided to go up there and he really enjoyed the experience and it changed. When he came back to begin that fall you could see the whole change in his mentality and he has become one of the leaders in the program now. In terms of whatever we do he's one of the first to volunteer for it, one of the first ones to step out front in what it is they're trying to do. So little successes like that is what helps keep all of us going that work with the program when we can see the growth in the students that we're working with.

just from working with them and what I've found is that some of our most intelligent kids didn't do well in high school. So it's kind of interesting and it may or may not translate over into college. So we've had some that didn't do well in high school, didn't score well on ACT, come into college and are doing great. Then we've had vice versa where some of them had high ACT scores, I mean we don't have any with a high ACT that are failing or anything but they did come in at the level that we expected. So we're really getting a mix range at least from among the MISTER's. I think what partially contributes to that is just the amount of stuff that they're engaged in and involved in. So they're juggling a lot of different things, not just coursework. The things that we're asking them to do and then they're getting all of this extra attention for being a part of this program and then all of their personal interests that they want to do some of everything at college. One of the things that I see them struggling with the most is just really trying to figure out how do we juggle all of these things that we want to do and how do we make decisions that are going to be best for us.

What I try to do is help support them without telling them what to do. My whole way of working with students is I'll talk to you but you're going to ultimately make the decision because I want you to be able to make decisions. If you're going to work with young children, if you're going to help them in the future you need to be able to recognize this process to know what it's like and help them make decisions without handicapping them by telling them what to do every time.

M: I do. I joke about it sometimes. Sometimes they get a little more attention than my nine year old does, at least academically. So, yes, I'm very involved with what they do. They can change the whole perspective on my day. When they're doing well that can make my day go very, very well. I can be having a great day and then one of them walks in my office and just messes it all up. So, again, I do kind of see myself as a father figure and again what I want to do is just help them make good decisions so that they can be the best that they can be in what they're doing.
