It varies week to week. Some of them I determine solely by myself. Some of them the guys will come to me and say, look, we need to talk about this. We're having a problem. Guys aren't showing up the way they should be showing up or they're late. We might have a whole meeting about that. The next meeting we're going to have is going to be about we just had midterms so it's time to find out how everyone performed in midterms. So we put everybody's grades on the board, on the whiteboard. Yes, and we sit and talk about what the problem is.

Yes, but again so we want them to know whether or not their brothers are struggling so again they can be there to help them or if they're not going to class they need to make sure that they're getting there. That's the whole idea of them being in a cohort and going through it together. So, yes, it's transparent. This year we just implemented an awards process. So we're giving them awards for highest GPA this year. We have like an athletic competition award so between the cohorts. So which cohort wins the most basketball games, shoots the best, at archery, those type things. We also have like an attendance award for events and then we're going to do like one overall called Call Me MISTER or something like this who is really exemplifying the qualities of a MISTER. So again that's something that they get really excited about and again the whole transparency of putting everything on the board kind of helps out with that process.

Faculty receive them well. They have high expectations for the students and again sometimes they live up them and sometimes they don't in terms of in the classroom. Now in the community they've been great going out and all the principals and the teachers they work with. They've had nothing but high praise for them and the job that they've been able to do with students. That's here in Jackson, Mississippi and at Clemson. Everything that we've ever heard about them has been great. So again I guess our challenge right now is to make sure that, okay, they understand that what you're doing in terms of working with the kids has to translate over into your coursework all the time. You need that in order to graduate. So I mean just because you may feel like you're being prepared pretty well to be a teacher you still have to produce in the classroom in order to get there.

I feel that the number one issue that we face here in Mississippi is that there is no compulsory early childhood education. That's a biggie. Again, we look at the different sections in Mississippi. If you go into areas like the Mississippi Delta a kid may not experience any type of formal education until they are six years old.

It's not compulsory, no. A small fraction, I don't have the numbers in front of me but I became keenly aware of this when I became superintendent in Yazoo City. I would watch kids go into first grade and there's a kid who has been with his grandmother or aunt his whole time. So he's speaking broken English, knows nothing about formal education. Then you have another child who has been in kindergarten or Head Start and that kid has been going or has some type of formal education since four years old. That kid is way ahead of the other kid. So that's the number one issue compulsory early childhood education. The second big issue is that Mississippi has a funding formula for the public schools. On record it says this is what should be done but that formula has never been fully funded. You're going to hear the terms in Mississippi of MAEP, Mississippi Adequate Education Program. It has never been fully funded and that's the big argument from the 152 school districts in Mississippi. Mississippi is very conservative, very conservative and of course public education is somewhat liberal. There are a lot of private schools in Mississippi, a lot of parochial schools. So when it comes to funding public schools it is terribly underfunded. That's the second issue.

You'll hear me talk about the Mississippi Delta a lot because it is really tragic what's going on there. It should be treated, I think, as a crisis or an epidemic but the state leadership they don't see it that way. It's really tragic. I wouldn't have known how awful it was growing up. I finished high school in 1976 and maybe I just didn't see it. But going back and being superintendent of schools in Yazoo City of which they call that the gateway to the Delta, it was tough. It was tough. It was the hardest job I've ever had in my life.

33% of all the students were one grade or two grades behind. Somewhere in the neighborhood of 65% or 70% was reading below proficient levels. In elementary school it was tragic but they had this situation where they were getting parents to sign consent forms to hold their kids back in first grade not realizing that if a kid fails before third grade there's a 45% chance they're not going to graduate. The Yazoo Public Schools were 99.9% African American but in both of the elementary schools it was like 95% Caucasian teachers.

It's mixed. When you look at Jackson local leadership it's predominately African American but when you look at the power structure it's dominated by whites. When you spread out and look at the state as a whole it is highly conservative.

Hispanics it's kind of migrant. It's seasonal. That's about it. The Native Americans are situated in Choctaw County, maybe anywhere from 75 to 100 miles from here. We have a great partnership with them. In fact, we train many of the Choctaw teachers through our lifelong learning endeavor. So we're very close to them. But mainly it's black and white.

and of course the third issue is going to be pay. Teachers in Mississippi they're the lowest, most of the time they are the lower in the southeast.

Another issue I think that confronts students as well as teachers is that they don't really have the necessary resources. Depending on where you are again you may go into a school in the Jackson area, Madison, Clinton, and you'll see a computer in every room, access to all kinds of technology. You may go into laces in the Mississippi Delta and you may not see a computer.

We have the Call Me MISTER program that's very similar that when they graduate they have got to come back and stay I believe a minimum of three years. We feel like if you're here for three years or four years you're going to stay here. We're trying to recruit more and more. Right now we have 15. This coming fall we will have 20 and hopefully other scholarships will kick in that we can really raise that number. Now, in the Call Me MISTER program it has a slightly different slant to it. What we do there is try and get African American males into challenged elementary schools. In Mississippi we do have a shortage of black males. Sometimes a student may not see a black male until maybe middle school and sometimes high school. It's even worse in very poor areas.

You'll hear me talk about the Mississippi Delta a lot because it is really tragic what's going on there. It should be treated, I think, as a crisis or an epidemic but the state leadership they don't see it that way. It's really tragic. I wouldn't have known how awful it was growing up. I finished high school in 1976 and maybe I just didn't see it. But going back and being superintendent of schools in Yazoo City of which they call that the gateway to the Delta, it was tough. It was tough. It was the hardest job I've ever had in my life.

I love data. So when I first got there I did some research. In middle school, for an example, 33% of all the students were one grade or two grades behind. Somewhere in the neighborhood of 65% or 70% was reading below proficient levels. In elementary school it was tragic but they had this situation where they were getting parents to sign consent forms to hold their kids back in first grade not realizing that if a kid fails before third grade there's a 45% chance they're not going to graduate. The Yazoo Public Schools were 99.9% African American but in both of the elementary schools it was like 95% Caucasian teachers. Their children were attending private schools.

Mississippi has what we call the Mississippi Teacher Shortage Act. So we were able to get a lot teachers in not just from Yazoo City but from surrounding areas. Things were really looking good until I was recruited back to Jackson State. It was time to go. Yazoo City, as I said, is a very political place. In four years I think we had done as much as we could do, in my estimation. It brought a change to the city. It brought some adrenalin to the city and it sort of woke some of the leaders up in that I guess I was a very polarizing figure for that particular four years. Either you love him or you hate him.

my most support came from liberal whites. The blacks were a little bit afraid. I'm not from Yazoo City. They viewed me as a Jacksonion, coming from Jackson telling them what to do. Teacher education, we do our best here at Jackson State to stay acquainted with the K-12 schools. That was my mission in coming here. I feel we do a great job.

when I got here there was a disconnect. What we did right away was that we started connecting with all of the K-12 schools. For an example, we actually developed something called the Mississippi Learning Instituted. It's funded by Kellogg and they actually train teachers, train students. We do induction. We put on conferences, reading conferences, urban education conferences. We connect in that we give professional development. Teachers have to have renewal, something called CEU's. So we offer those. In addition to that we started what we call the Curriculum Center. The Curriculum Center is K-12. We hired an assistant principal to run the Curriculum Center. So she is keenly aware. I think she is the smartest person here. She makes that connection. She is a K-12 resource for the College of Education.

Most of my hires have been people who work in K-12. The lady in the Curriculum Center, we have two professors in ed leadership who are former principals. In elementary education, our last three hires have been former teachers. So that's the greatest way that we're making a connection to really get to get K-12 people in here.

It varies. Most of our student teachers go the Jackson Public Schools. They do have a discipline issue in Jackson Public Schools. So with that in mind we try and give them the latest strategies and methodologies on classroom management, time on task instruction, making sure that we offset the discipline issues as much as possible. Jackson Public Schools has an issue with Special Education. We can't help them a lot there because our Special Education numbers are extremely low. The other issue...

m one of the few people in the country who have experienced education at all levels. I started out as a teacher in Jackson Public Schools after graduating from Jackson State University. This is my home school. Also I've served as an assistant principal, principal, superintendent of schools in the Mississippi delta, a place Yazoo City. From there I was recruited back to Jackson State really to be Director of Teacher Education because there had been a disconnect between K-12 and colleges of education. So I was brought here to make that connection. From there I became Associate Dean and eventually became Interim Dean and became Dean. I was Director of Teacher Education starting in 2003, Associate Dean in 2005, Interim Dean in 2006 and eventually Dean in 2007. So I've experienced education at all levels and I'm ex-military. When I left the Mississippi Delta I joined the Air Force because we were extremely poor. So paid my way through school on something called the GI Bill.

From there I was recruited back to Jackson State really to be Director of Teacher Education because there had been a disconnect between K-12 and colleges of education. So I was brought here to make that connection. From there I became Associate Dean and eventually became Interim Dean and became Dean. I was Director of Teacher Education starting in 2003, Associate Dean in 2005, Interim Dean in 2006 and eventually Dean in 2007.

Teach for Mississippi. It is multifaceted. The proposal has been sent to the Provost who eventually will send it to the President. It's a way of getting more and more teachers. This fall we should have 13 online programs, two of which will be a master's and specialist in Special Education. So we'll have 13 online programs starting this fall. In addition to that we're trying to twist the President's arm to offer scholarships to valedictorians and salutatorians with a certain SAT score and ACT score around the country and also here in Mississippi.

Teach for Mississippi. In addition to that, in the 152 school districts in Mississippi we are going to try and put organizations in as many school districts as possible in high school and middle school be a teacher. We want to teach them about being a teacher. We want to give them everything we can on what it takes to be a teacher, the effect that they'll make, what it does to you from an intrinsic standpoint. We want them to join this organization. We're hoping that in the summer we can bring them to Jackson State University, let them live on campus. We feel that in the long run it's going to build that teacher pool that we so badly need. Hopefully I can give you a copy of it before you leave.

We get a good number of teachers from Jackson Public Schools. So it's home and they go back. Of course we have certain scholarships where they have to stay within the state. I don't have my finger on that percentage but generally what happens is we get kids from Chicago, Atlanta, and they go back to Chicago or Atlanta. But then sometimes they stay. They have a good experience and they don't want to go back to Chicago, they don't want to go back to Atlanta. They say hey we want to stay here. So we're able to keep them here. It's a warm climate; it's a good place to live. It's nothing special we do to keep them here unless they use scholarship money and then they're obligated

Another issue I think that confronts students as well as teachers is that they don't really have the necessary resources. Depending on where you are again you may go into a school in the Jackson area, Madison, Clinton, and you'll see a computer in every room, access to all kinds of technology. You may go into laces in the Mississippi Delta and you may not see a computer.

Well, when I got here there was a disconnect. What we did right away was that we started connecting with all of the K-12 schools. For an example, we actually developed something called the Mississippi Learning Instituted. It's funded by Kellogg and they actually train teachers, train students. We do induction. We put on conferences, reading conferences, urban education conferences. We connect in that we give professional development. Teachers have to have renewal, something called CEU's. So we offer those. In addition to that we started what we call the Curriculum Center. The Curriculum Center is K-12. We hired an assistant principal to run the Curriculum Center. So she is keenly aware. I think she is the smartest person here. She makes that connection. She is a K-12 resource for the College of Education.

We want them to join this organization. We're hoping that in the summer we can bring them to Jackson State University, let them live on campus.

Call Me MISTER program that's very similar that when they graduate they have got to come back and stay I believe a minimum of three years. We feel like if you're here for three years or four years you're going to stay here. We're trying to recruit more and more. Right now we have 15. This coming fall we will have 20 and hopefully other scholarships will kick in that we can really raise that number. Now, in the Call Me MISTER program it has a slightly different slant to it. What we do there is try and get African American males into challenged elementary schools. In Mississippi we do have a shortage of black males. Sometimes a student may not see a black male until maybe middle school and sometimes high school. It's even worse in very poor areas.

my most support came from liberal whites. The blacks were a little bit afraid. I'm not from Yazoo City. They viewed me as a Jacksonion, coming from Jackson telling them what to do. A lot of the blacks their employment is tied into white's conservative ones so they had to be very careful, very careful about how they supported or not supported me.

Is the potential to do something special. There are a lot of great people in the Jackson area. A lot of good people, a lot of people who know the way things should be and to fight real hard to make it like that. Of course the climate is good; food is good. It's a very spiritual area; churches are good.

When I interviewed for the job I observed that my first seven, the first seven Presidents while they were all very distinguished none of them were born in California nor in this area. I grew up just 40 miles from the campus. My grandparents immigrated here from Mexico. My great grandfather helped to build the railroad through the San Joaquin Valley and my grandfather who raised me ended up residing in Hanford which is in Kings County. I went away to college at Berkeley and at Stanford and I served in the UC system for about 23 years. About a year before I became President I decided I wanted to try to be a President because for me it kind of brought everything together. Early on in high school I wanted to focus on leadership and public service but it wasn't until I became a student at Berkeley where I really understood the impact that universities can have on peoples' lives, the transformational impact. So for me serving in a university became kind of a focus of my career as a professor and administrator and how as President. It's deeply meaningful to be here at this time. There's just been an incredible about of support from the community for what we're trying to do.

As you said we're both Hispanic serving and we're AANAPISI or Asian American and Native Alaskan Pacific Islander. That's a mouthful. And we're proud of that. You might have heard from our folks as well that over 70% of our students are first in their families to go to college which makes us an even more unique place. Over 60%, probably getting close to 2/3rds are Pell Grant students as well. I think we'll probably be at about 80% first generation very soon just because of the growth that we're seeing. The demand to come here is at an all time high and it's very exciting. It's challenging because we can't accommodate everybody but as I travel around the Central Valley there's just a lot of interest and support and excitement.

The focus of my presidency is student success. While the institution had focused on that before I think we're doing it in a much more intensive intentional way. We're getting ready to put together a new strategic plan and that will be at the core of it. So everything that we've done since I've been here has been about investing more in supporting our students and also strengthening our infrastructure to support our students and our faculty, education and research as well. We do applied research here, so a little different than at the research university setting but very exciting and deeply impactful. We have the ag research center in our system opening up in January and we're very excited about that. That's been a real focus as well of my presidency is to look at agriculture and how it can really blossom. This is really the epicenter for agriculture in the whole world. If you were to look at the major industries and players in agriculture you would have them very near Fresno and in and around of many of the major industries. A lot of those folks are alumni but interestingly they had not been as connected to us as they can be and will be. So a lot of focus has been put into that. We're recruiting for a new dean for that college and starting to get more specific with you but that is certainly going to be more and more an area of focus and getting more diverse students in that field as well so that the farm worker's children of all backgrounds and a lot of Hmong farm worker's children as well who are looking at this field.

Oh, absolutely. The Southeast Asian population is very important and a growing population. I believe that we have one of the largest percentages of Hmong students in the nation. They came here for political reasons. Many of them have gone into agriculture, the parents have. I'd like to position our college so that we serve a greater diversity of students including more Southeast Asian students and look at different kinds of crops. I think there is lots of potential in that area. We have a 1,000 acre farm where we can do a lot of that experimentation. For example, they weren't growing jalapeno peppers and it's like why wouldn't we do that in Fresno with the population that we have.

So that's just one example of just trying to make it a more inclusive dynamic place for everyone. That's very important to me, to our cabinet. We've got almost a completely new cabinet. The one that my predecessor had was together for the most part for ten years and very talented folks. A lot of them were scheduled for retirement so it gave me the chance to search. We have appointed our top choice in every search for candidates. Most of them we now have a majority of cabinet members who graduate from this institution. I did not but the Provost has, our Vice President for Advancement, our Vice President for Administration, my Chief of Staff, our Communications Vice President. They all graduated from here. All but one of them grew up here. So it's got a really distinct flavor of local people and that's important to me because there's this message that goes out across this region from businesses and some public entities that it's very difficult to attract talent. I want to bottle that. I think we've shown that you can bring in really top notch people. We just recruited our athletic director, for example, from the University of Oregon. He help them ascend to the highest level but he grew up in the Valley. So when this job came open he wasn't looking for a new job but we called him and said what do you think. This is a great time to be at Fresno State and we're rising and do you want to join us and he said yes. So we've got a collection of people who care deeply about the campus and the region, who have family, who have friends here. So they have this sense of ownership that goes beyond professional. For me as President that's so meaningful to serve here in my home makes such a huge difference. It's not just 23,000 students. I mean these are folks who sat in the same desks that I did and so I understand a lot of what they've experienced and I want them to succeed. We all believe in them and so that's part of, that's a very important part of why we're here and what we're doing.

Well, for me I think conceptually I want everyone here and our 200,000 alumni, 80% of whom live in this region. We have 160,000 alumni right here. So as I travel around to every city in our region they're the mayors and they're the doctors, they're the teachers, they're the professors in the local community colleges or the teachers in the schools and so forth. So I want us all to be on the same page that this institution is about transforming the lives of the students who come here and to position them for the changes that are occurring out in our society in the workforce. So it's all about making sure that they don't just arrive. There hasn't been a huge emphasis on access and I love that. I want to preserve that. There had not been as much of an intentional focus on that person and their experience here and their roadmap to success. I believe that now we have that intentional focus and it's supported at the highest level by our Board of Trustees and by Chancellor White. We have targets for graduation rates and programs and plans but it goes beyond that. It goes to the heart of how we organize our work, so how we schedule classes, how we advise our students, whether we have recreational spaces here. In the past there had been the emphasis was we go to the local high school and play club sports instead of stay here. So it's an emphasis on making sure that every student thrives and that they feel comfortable here and that they spend as much time here. It's not oh I've got to go there for two hours for a class and then running somewhere else whether it's a job or some other obligation. I want to do whatever we can to keep them here for as much as they can be here realizing they have different obligations but making this a place where if you walk through the library at the noon hour you'll see hundreds and hundreds of students and at 5:00 the same. This place is a beehive of activity. Outside not so much. We have a lot of nice days here and I'd love to make the whole campus part of the learning experience in ways that it hasn't so far. With technology you can do that. So that's what I'm thinking about at that highest level. Yes, I think it will translate into higher graduation rates. I actually think the 70% rate that we've set for the next ten years I think, between us, we're going to climb over that much soon just the way we've been climbing. I think we'll climb over it faster.

At the end of my first year last year was 52 and they tell me that it will probably be about 55 or so. Some of the faculty feel like I'm pushing this too hard but I'm going to keep pushing because I think that it's that intentionality that it's not just I'm going to get to meet this student and nice having them on campus for a few years. This system, our system was actually built around losing half of our students. The financial formula, the enrollment formula, all of that and if you look at the line, the graduation rate over say the 15 years before it was essentially flat lined around 49% or 50%. So I think that we can change that dramatically. The other effect of doing that is that we'll attract students from all backgrounds, including the children of our alumni. I found that some of our alumni were sending their children elsewhere because they felt like they weren't going to get a quality experience like they may have had when they came.

Hopefully you'll hear more. We just rolled that out in the fall and that initiative again is about student success but it's also about understanding the changes in technology. So we're moving for them from textbooks to the tablet. Some professors are beginning to customize their own materials. What we've seen is a much higher level of engagement by the students and the faculty in these redesigned courses. We've lower textbook costs by 55%. Actually at Apple last week we had some very interesting conversations about student learning and changing the way in which textbooks are created. They were urging us to have the students in the course write the textbook with the faculty member for the next course. They have found that students who are engaged in that way do better.

Yeah, and we hadn't thought about it in quite that way but now we are. It has implications for the kind of faculty that we would hire to do that as well. So this program is just starting. We're going to scale it to 5,000, which would be about 20 plus percent of our student body and then eventually scale it up higher. We might have all freshmen eventually in this program in stages. But we've done it all through faculty volunteers so it hasn't been mandated. It's been through inspiring instead of requiring.

every college in school is involved in it and has faculty in the program. Then we went undergrad and grad as well. It's possible that in a later stage we might look at some groupings by year but for right now we actually had the faculty self-identity. So if that faculty member was teaching a course then that would become a tablet course and then we're going to scale it from there. It's worked out. I think for us it was the right cultural move because it enabled them to be empowered to say I want to get in on that.

Absolutely. Earlier in my career I had served here as part of the UC Merced campus and worked with a lot of the educators here and Fresno State folks Fresno State has very long term relationships with districts that go beyond individual superintendents and principals. We've been here a hundred years so over that period some really great institutional relationships have been developed. I think that's one of the secrets of the success here. The other is having those strong leaders in different positions whether it's superintendents or school board members, active teachers. I think because so many of them are our alumni that that has really helped to solidify the connections and those alumni have had good experiences because if they had negative experiences it would have been harder. We find ways to stay connected with them. So in a few days I'll be in a room. I was last week in a room with all the Fresno County K-12 superintendents and I'll be in a room again with many of them next week. So there are groupings that get together on a regular basis. The superintendent of Fresno Unified he and I talk almost every day about something and I know the Dean does as well. So those connections are very strong. I think that as we focus even more on success I think we'll find that even more students will want to come here and study whether it's in the credentialing program or other fields that we have across the campus. So I think you'll see those programs becoming stronger and stronger over time.

I'm with you. You raise a great issue about hunger. I don't know if this came up with your professors but last year a study was done by one of our graduate students who is now on the faculty of our students at Fresno State and found that 30% of our students here at Fresno State were and are food insecure.

They miss one or two meals a day. They were clearly, it was impacting everything. So we rolled out an initiative beginning last fall and we were just talking at cabinet this morning. We have a philanthropist who's going to buy, essentially we're going to lease them the land. They're going to build this large home on the campus and it will house our cupboard, which is like going to your grandma's and it will have food. We have a temporary space now that's being used extensively. All you have to do is take your card, your ID, and you can pick the things that you need. It's food and toiletries. But with this philanthropist's support we're going to have a house so that the homeless students will be able to stay there for a short period. They can get food and there will actually be a kitchen for cooking demonstrations so that students know. A lot of our students don't cook very often or very much and that might mean that they're spending more than they need to. So we're trying to educate them about that. But dealing with this hunger issue is a high priority for us because I don't think there's any way that they can succeed when they're hungry.

it really has been an amazing experience to see. The students themselves help us to develop the initiative so I think that's why they're being utilized so effectively. We had 600 in the first month come to the cupboard and 600 in the second month. A lot of those are probably undocumented because we have about 400 or 500 undocumented students. We still can't offer them Pell Grants until the DREAM Act is passed. So their financial situation is precarious. A lot of them were suffering in silence because they're the first in their families to go to college. They are the role models and they don't want to say to their parents, in fact their parents might be suffering more. So they suffer in silence. It was this thing, I mean this study has opened my eyes. Some of them were even dumpster diving and just scrounging around. It's like our students have to do that is just so painful to understand and believe. It's been exciting and a lot of our ag alumni are stepping up. They're donating. We have one alum who is one of the largest peach producers in the whole world. They sell the peach cuts to all the school around the nations. So they're giving those to us. Another guy has fresh chickens and giving those to us. We're trying to get as much as we can for them.

I was meeting, and I know we all have to go. The other day I was with the Chief of Staff for Chancellor White, who is my boss. They were in a trustees meeting talking about the diversity of CSU. The Chancellor turns to him and says, “Which campus do you think is the most diverse?” His Chief of Staff, I was surprised, he goes, “Fresno because Fresno has significant populations of many kinds of students.” While some campuses might highlight one or two just the mix that we have is quite unique even in an overall very unique system. So it was interesting that he had that insight and I'm proud of that.

By next year, because of demand, that will mean that no one from outside the area regardless of their GPA could get in. So I've now begun conversations with them and we're having town halls about how we change this because it's an unsustainable path. It would mean that young people who share the diverse background of our students who might live just outside the boundaries of the four counties who want to study agriculture or engineering...

raise the requirements for the four county students and a small number, 400 or 500 of those, would no longer be admitted here. That would leave some room for those from outside the four county service area who meet higher levels of requirements to continue to have access. But then the implications for that are we've got to make sure that parents and students understand the changes and they can go to a community college.

So we've got work to do here. We've got a lot of work to do here because our mini corps students are a small percentage of our students. Wouldn't it be amazing if every student in our program came from a mini corps-ish background, had multiple years of embedded experience in area classrooms and learning about the cultures of the families and learning about the contexts in which our students come from, in which our K-12 students live and being integrated intimately into that world before they go into teaching with that scaffolding and support? There's no coincidence that every one of those kids were dressed in professional business attire before they came. Jose and Lilly are like family to the mini corps kids. Mentoring just doesn't, there's no end, there's no limit to the mentoring that they get in that context.

completely new cabinet. The one that my predecessor had was together for the most part for ten years and very talented folks. A lot of them were scheduled for retirement so it gave me the chance to search. We have appointed our top choice in every search for candidates. Most of them we now have a majority of cabinet members who graduate from this institution.

the Provost has, our Vice President for Advancement, our Vice President for Administration, my Chief of Staff, our Communications Vice President. They all graduated from here. All but one of them grew up here. So it's got a really distinct flavor of local people and that's important to me because there's this message that goes out across this region from businesses and some public entities that it's very difficult to attract talent.

I'm actually really lucky in that regard because most people in the education program only work with credential and master students and then some people work also with our doctoral program. I get to work with incoming freshman. I teach an academic literacy course that I started teaching when I was still adjunct. It's a cohorted model called First Year Experience for 100 students each year. They are the most at risk students on our campus. Every student in this cohort is first generation. Every student in this cohort has met minimum requirements to attend this university but has failed both English and math placement exams. So if they don't remediate within that first year they're not allowed to stay. I get to teach one of their only GE courses that year. Academic reading is a special designation course that they get GE credit for. I get to work with 100 freshmen, 18 year olds, first time, first generation freshmen every year. So I really get to know more about the campus culture than a lot of people but I also work with credential students and grad students in my more typically literacy courses.

your relationship with your colleagues here in your area and just kind of like the way that you work together in order to achieve the goals with regard to teacher education.  I think it's a pretty congenial group of people in general. Everybody seems very friendly and everybody gets along but there are definitely pockets of people who are active and who are working, are here every day and are working on multiple, have three or four balls in the air at all times and who really are doing the hard work of wanting to affect change. Then there are the others who will smile at you in the hallway but are also kind of reveling in the fact that they teach their three courses and have lots of free time because they published their three articles that they needed for tenure and they're never going to lift a pen again or write another word. There are faculty here who stay current and who are going to AERA and other major conferences every year and are publishing and are researching their own practice. Then there are others who have not even read any research for the past 10 to 15 years.

I have found my little niche of likeminded people and every day is exciting because we're always doing something. Last week I was working with a colleague friend who is on the liberal studies grant with me. We were visiting all of the department chairs of all of the content areas engaged in the world studies all across campus. So we got to take all of these fabulous walks and meet all these people. We were telling them about the grant and the work we're doing and inviting them to participate and offering them money. It was this very exciting moment where we were making these kinds of connections. Kathy and I used this monitor to collaborate in writing. Much of the grant we wrote for you was written on this TV screen with Google Docs. -0:10:07- Kathy Louda and I are working on another study of the childcare center downstairs and how translanguaging is a perfect fit for the Reggio Emilia Approach to preschool. We've submitted both an article and a LRA proposal. So I think there's like this really vibrant little group of us who are just, again, I think we all see the same thing which is anything we can want to happen or imagine happening we can make happen. There's no one stopping us and there's tons of support from our Dean. It's just a matter of the work that you're willing to put in.

I love coming to work every single day. I don't think I ever loved anything as much as I love this job in my adult life of work and school. I mean I love teaching but this is so, every day is so exciting and it's not the same ever. In that sense I feel really lucky.

There is a faculty member who runs the liberal studies, what do we call them, the liberal studies meetings twice a month. Liberal studies team? No. I don't know what they're called. Anyway, she runs the liberal studies, she's the liaison to all of these people. She has been sort of a push back person since our other grant started or since the planning stages of this other grant saying that the liberal studies committee or the people on it are not going to want to participate. They don't want to do anything, they're naysayers, you're not going to win them over. Then she's told us we can't cohort students. Students in a cohort doesn't work in a model. She's just put up all of these barriers and blamed all of the barriers on all of these other people. We've managed to talk to all of these people and find out that they're actually really excited. The advisors would love to cohort people because it would be easier for everybody and the students would not have to worry about enrolling in classes.

The faculty want the opportunity and the time and the space to unpack Common Core, the CSET standards and figure out what their syllabi, how they're missing the mark because we do have a really severe issue with our students not meeting the high stakes barriers and not being able to continue or complete their credentials. But I think a little bit of perseverance and not taking no for an answer has been one way. But I think that's only one example because I think in other ways sometimes you can finesse it without having to do a little steamrolling. There are people who have been here a long time who are not necessarily going to want to look at their syllabi and rethink them. There are people on campus who are not going to want to add current research to their research courses. I'm not going to be able to steamroll everyone because I'm not in charge of the world. I'm not the king of this school. So I think in those cases sometimes it's just going to be ongoing dialog and conversation and sometimes ongoing conversations that aren't fun or comfortable to have but that need to be had, need to be done.

Oh, absolutely. The Southeast Asian population is very important and a growing population. I believe that we have one of the largest percentages of Hmong students in the nation. They came here for political reasons. Many of them have gone into agriculture, the parents have. I'd like to position our college so that we serve a greater diversity of students including more Southeast Asian students and look at different kinds of crops. I think there is lots of potential in that area. We have a 1,000 acre farm where we can do a lot of that experimentation. For example, they weren't growing jalapeno peppers and it's like why wouldn't we do that in Fresno with the population that we have.

Well, for me I think conceptually I want everyone here and our 200,000 alumni, 80% of whom live in this region. We have 160,000 alumni right here. So as I travel around to every city in our region they're the mayors and they're the doctors, they're the teachers, they're the professors in the local community colleges or the teachers in the schools and so forth. So I want us all to be on the same page that this institution is about transforming the lives of the students who come here and to position them for the changes that are occurring out in our society in the workforce. So it's all about making sure that they don't just arrive. There hasn't been a huge emphasis on access and I love that. I want to preserve that. There had not been as much of an intentional focus on that person and their experience here and their roadmap to success. I believe that now we have that intentional focus and it's supported at the highest level by our Board of Trustees and by Chancellor White. We have targets for graduation rates and programs and plans but it goes beyond that. It goes to the heart of how we organize our work, so how we schedule classes, how we advise our students, whether we have recreational spaces here. In the past there had been the emphasis was we go to the local high school and play club sports instead of stay here. So it's an emphasis on making sure that every student thrives and that they feel comfortable here and that they spend as much time here. It's not oh I've got to go there for two hours for a class and then running somewhere else whether it's a job or some other obligation. I want to do whatever we can to keep them here for as much as they can be here realizing they have different obligations but making this a place where if you walk through the library at the noon hour you'll see hundreds and hundreds of students and at 5:00 the same. This place is a beehive of activity. Outside not so much. We have a lot of nice days here and I'd love to make the whole campus part of the learning experience in ways that it hasn't so far. With technology you can do that. So that's what I'm thinking about at that highest level. Yes, I think it will translate into higher graduation rates. I actually think the 70% rate that we've set for the next ten years I think, between us, we're going to climb over that much soon just the way we've been climbing. I think we'll climb over it faster.

At the end of my first year last year was 52 and they tell me that it will probably be about 55 or so. Some of the faculty feel like I'm pushing this too hard but I'm going to keep pushing because I think that it's that intentionality that it's not just I'm going to get to meet this student and nice having them on campus for a few years. This system, our system was actually built around losing half of our students. The financial formula, the enrollment formula, all of that and if you look at the line, the graduation rate over say the 15 years before it was essentially flat lined around 49% or 50%. So I think that we can change that dramatically. The other effect of doing that is that we'll attract students from all backgrounds, including the children of our alumni. I found that some of our alumni were sending their children elsewhere because they felt like they weren't going to get a quality experience like they may have had when they came.

Messaging and everybody, I want this to be a destination university for students from all backgrounds. I think that that message is resonating with a lot of parents who are seeing that we're investing more in the success of our students. We're positioning ourselves more as being engaged with technology. We were just at Apple last week talking about some new ways to partner around our DISCOVERe tablet initiative. Have they shared with you anything about that initiative?

Yes. Northridge rolled one out a year before us and we learned a lot from them. They decided that they were going to focus in on juniors in certain fields. When we looked at that we decided it would be better for us to go campus wide. So every college in school is involved in it and has faculty in the program. Then we went undergrad and grad as well. It's possible that in a later stage we might look at some groupings by year but for right now we actually had the faculty self-identity. So if that faculty member was teaching a course then that would become a tablet course and then we're going to scale it from there. It's worked out. I think for us it was the right cultural move because it enabled them to be empowered to say I want to get in on that

Early on in high school I wanted to focus on leadership and public service but it wasn't until I became a student at Berkeley where I really understood the impact that universities can have on peoples' lives, the transformational impact. So for me serving in a university became kind of a focus of my career as a professor and administrator and how as President. It's deeply meaningful to be here at this time. There's just been an incredible about of support from the community for what we're trying to do.

By next year, because of demand, that will mean that no one from outside the area regardless of their GPA could get in. So I've now begun conversations with them and we're having town halls about how we change this because it's an unsustainable path. It would mean that young people who share the diverse background of our students who might live just outside the boundaries of the four counties who want to study agriculture or engineering...

raise the requirements for the four county students and a small number, 400 or 500 of those, would no longer be admitted here. That would leave some room for those from outside the four county service area who meet higher levels of requirements to continue to have access. But then the implications for that are we've got to make sure that parents and students understand the changes and they can go to a community college.

When I interviewed for the job I observed that my first seven, the first seven Presidents while they were all very distinguished none of them were born in California nor in this area. I grew up just 40 miles from the campus. My grandparents immigrated here from Mexico. My great grandfather helped to build the railroad through the San Joaquin Valley and my grandfather who raised me ended up residing in Hanford which is in Kings County. I went away to college at Berkeley and at Stanford and I served in the UC system for about 23 years. About a year before I became President I decided I wanted to try to be a President because for me it kind of brought everything together. Early on in high school I wanted to focus on leadership and public service but it wasn't until I became a student at Berkeley where I really understood the impact that universities can have on peoples' lives, the transformational impact. So for me serving in a university became kind of a focus of my career as a professor and administrator and how as President. It's deeply meaningful to be here at this time. There's just been an incredible about of support from the community for what we're trying to do.

Hopefully you'll hear more. We just rolled that out in the fall and that initiative again is about student success but it's also about understanding the changes in technology. So we're moving for them from textbooks to the tablet. Some professors are beginning to customize their own materials. What we've seen is a much higher level of engagement by the students and the faculty in these redesigned courses. We've lower textbook costs by 55%. Actually at Apple last week we had some very interesting conversations about student learning and changing the way in which textbooks are created. They were urging us to have the students in the course write the textbook with the faculty member for the next course. They have found that students who are engaged in that way do better.
That's what we're finding, giving them the tools and we've invested a lot in faculty development so that they could redesign their courses, so they know about resources that they could use.

Absolutely. Earlier in my career I had served here as part of the UC Merced campus and worked with a lot of the educators here and Fresno State folks Fresno State has very long term relationships with districts that go beyond individual superintendents and principals. We've been here a hundred years so over that period some really great institutional relationships have been developed. I think that's one of the secrets of the success here. The other is having those strong leaders in different positions whether it's superintendents or school board members, active teachers. I think because so many of them are our alumni that that has really helped to solidify the connections and those alumni have had good experiences because if they had negative experiences it would have been harder. We find ways to stay connected with them. So in a few days I'll be in a room. I was last week in a room with all the Fresno County K-12 superintendents and I'll be in a room again with many of them next week. So there are groupings that get together on a regular basis. The superintendent of Fresno Unified he and I talk almost every day about something and I know the Dean does as well. So those connections are very strong. I think that as we focus even more on success I think we'll find that even more students will want to come here and study whether it's in the credentialing program or other fields that we have across the campus. So I think you'll see those programs becoming stronger and stronger over time.

They couldn't come. So I think what we're going to do, we're still having discussions is we're going to raise the requirements for the four county students and a small number, 400 or 500 of those, would no longer be admitted here. That would leave some room for those from outside the four county service area who meet higher levels of requirements to continue to have access. But then the implications for that are we've got to make sure that parents and students understand the changes and they can go to a community college. We're keeping that path the same so that in two years they can come to see us. But it's that intentional focus together on what are the issues, what are the decisions that we have to make together and how can we help each other retrain the teachers that are working with them to prepare the students to come here. So we're implicated in so many ways and I'm well aware that in the past, not necessarily here but across the nation, university presidents and others will say to K-12 do a better job and prepare those students better but it's really all of us together. I've never believed in that approach. I don't think it's a very productive line. I think it's more about how do we focus together on a success even if preschool students all the way through higher education. So how do we support Head Start and First 5 efforts here and that sort of thing so that we're all a part of one team. I think that's helped a lot.

They miss one or two meals a day. They were clearly, it was impacting everything. So we rolled out an initiative beginning last fall and we were just talking at cabinet this morning. We have a philanthropist who's going to buy, essentially we're going to lease them the land. They're going to build this large home on the campus and it will house our cupboard, which is like going to your grandma's and it will have food. We have a temporary space now that's being used extensively. All you have to do is take your card, your ID, and you can pick the things that you need. It's food and toiletries. But with this philanthropist's support we're going to have a house so that the homeless students will be able to stay there for a short period. They can get food and there will actually be a kitchen for cooking demonstrations so that students know. A lot of our students don't cook very often or very much and that might mean that they're spending more than they need to. So we're trying to educate them about that. But dealing with this hunger issue is a high priority for us because I don't think there's any way that they can succeed when they're hungry.

t really has been an amazing experience to see. The students themselves help us to develop the initiative so I think that's why they're being utilized so effectively. We had 600 in the first month come to the cupboard and 600 in the second month. A lot of those are probably undocumented because we have about 400 or 500 undocumented students. We still can't offer them Pell Grants until the DREAM Act is passed. So their financial situation is precarious. A lot of them were suffering in silence because they're the first in their families to go to college. They are the role models and they don't want to say to their parents, in fact their parents might be suffering more. So they suffer in silence. It was this thing, I mean this study has opened my eyes. Some of them were even dumpster diving and just scrounging around. It's like our students have to do that is just so painful to understand and believe. It's been exciting and a lot of our ag alumni are stepping up. They're donating. We have one alum who is one of the largest peach producers in the whole world. They sell the peach cuts to all the school around the nations. So they're giving those to us. Another guy has fresh chickens and giving those to us. We're trying to get as much as we can for them.

focus of my presidency is student success. While the institution had focused on that before I think we're doing it in a much more intensive intentional way. We're getting ready to put together a new strategic plan and that will be at the core of it. This just seemed like the best place. I didn't want to leave California and this seemed like the best place to affect change in a community in all of the state. It just seemed like there was nothing but opportunity here and so here we are and here we stay.

The one thing I say about Fresno State a lot of people in my program thought I was crazy to apply to one school and say the Hail Mary and get in. Most people go on a national search and want to be all over the place. We were already pretty much settled here but beside the fact that I had geography as a factor in my taking the job one thing I say about this place is if you can dream it or imagine it you can make it happen. There is so much opportunity on this campus. If you had a more deficit perspective you might say that there is so much need or there is so much that needs to happen or that should happen here. What I see is just nothing but opportunity and a lot of support for making any kind of change happen. So our Dean has been incredibly supportive of people who are actively researching and impacting practice.

I think it's a pretty congenial group of people in general. Everybody seems very friendly and everybody gets along but there are definitely pockets of people who are active and who are working, are here every day and are working on multiple, have three or four balls in the air at all times and who really are doing the hard work of wanting to affect change. Then there are the others who will smile at you in the hallway but are also kind of reveling in the fact that they teach their three courses and have lots of free time because they published their three articles that they needed for tenure and they're never going to lift a pen again or write another word. There are faculty here who stay current and who are going to AERA and other major conferences every year and are publishing and are researching their own practice. Then there are others who have not even read any research for the past 10 to 15 years.

I love coming to work every single day. I don't think I ever loved anything as much as I love this job in my adult life of work and school. I mean I love teaching but this is so, every day is so exciting and it's not the same ever. In that sense I feel really lucky.

Room 100 downstairs. It's the advising office. They're told of all of the different opportunities that we have for students in liberal studies. We have another group called teaching fellows which is a much, much lighter version of the mini corps in terms of how much time the students spend in classroom settings and how much scaffolding and support they get in those roles. But they do get some extended education in literacy development and then they go out and provide tutoring services. So it's not to the same degree but they do have another, this is another opportunity that they can have. We have Build a Teacher Club, we have different courses they can take. They get guidance and advising on, they have to select within liberal studies is a wide array of courses and then they have to pick an emphasis area and they have to take a nine unit segment of classes that follow a continuum within one area.

There is a faculty member who runs the liberal studies, what do we call them, the liberal studies meetings twice a month. Liberal studies team? No. I don't know what they're called. Anyway, she runs the liberal studies, she's the liaison to all of these people. She has been sort of a push back person since our other grant started or since the planning stages of this other grant saying that the liberal studies committee or the people on it are not going to want to participate. They don't want to do anything, they're naysayers, you're not going to win them over. Then she's told us we can't cohort students. Students in a cohort doesn't work in a model. She's just put up all of these barriers and blamed all of the barriers on all of these other people. We've managed to talk to all of these people and find out that they're actually really excited. The advisors would love to cohort people because it would be easier for everybody and the students would not have to worry about enrolling in classes.

The faculty want the opportunity and the time and the space to unpack Common Core, the CSET standards and figure out what their syllabi, how they're missing the mark because we do have a really severe issue with our students not meeting the high stakes barriers and not being able to continue or complete their credentials. But I think a little bit of perseverance and not taking no for an answer has been one way. But I think that's only one example because I think in other ways sometimes you can finesse it without having to do a little steamrolling. There are people who have been here a long time who are not necessarily going to want to look at their syllabi and rethink them. There are people on campus who are not going to want to add current research to their research courses. I'm not going to be able to steamroll everyone because I'm not in charge of the world. I'm not the king of this school. So I think in those cases sometimes it's just going to be ongoing dialog and conversation and sometimes ongoing conversations that aren't fun or comfortable to have but that need to be had, need to be done.

Most of our liberal studies students if they set foot in a classroom once before they go into their, before they enter the credential program they have to do Ed 50 which is, what, 50 or 60 hours of observation and participation in a classroom, which they typically do in their last semester. But prior to that requirement for entry into the program we have probably the greatest percentage of our students who are never in a classroom setting and who don't have field experience and don't have service learning and aren't looking at teaching as transformation. They're looking at it as a job. In fact I would say if there's one thing I can do before I retire and stop doing anything it would be to have a larger percentage of students understand teaching as a transformative event. That's why I left the classroom because I could only do that in my own space rather than making that happen on a larger scale.

So what we think in terms of CSET is, yes, they need test prep and there is a lot of talk about test prep and there's a lot of talk about understanding, unpacking it and understanding the content and doing the test practices and all of this other stuff that makes my toes curl. But what we really want them to do is step back from the test one step and understand that it is a barrier and understand historically what this means on a great context and understand what does it mean that the faculty in your liberal studies program who taught the course that was supposed to prepare you for this don't even know what's on that test. Sometimes in order to really make change and be transformative you've got to sort of rally everybody and insight a little bit of frustration about the status quo. The status quo in our opinion is not addressing these needs in a mindful way, in a multitude of context. So our role is we're not just lighting a fire under the mini corps students and telling them hey this kind of blows that they didn't prepare you but we're now also working with all of our liberal studies faculty to ask them the difficult questions.

we're trying to work in all of these different spheres with the ultimate goal of, yes, this sort of pragmatic gatekeeping device but we don't want to stop there. We don't want to be just go take your test prep course and then you'll be okay and then you can move on with your life and with your job. We want our students who ultimately pass CSET to say hey this is a lot like what students in my classroom will face when the high stakes standardized testing comes through. I'm making decisions about teaching what I know is right versus teaching what I know is on the test and how am I going to walk that tightrope so that my students both have access to the culture of power but also have the ability to resist and to work around it and outside of it.
I'm actually really lucky in that regard because most people in the education program only work with credential and master students and then some people work also with our doctoral program.

What I find in general with the students here is that they are so appreciative of faculty who demonstrate that they care. So there is this reciprocal relationship. There are a lot of faculty who phone it in or who come in and have an attitude of do it my way or whatever. But the students really recognize faculty who don't have that stance. So I feel like it's not just me going in with my way of being in the classroom but it's like there's a give and take there. I run into students in the community all the time who will talk about something that changed their lives. I just feel like there's a recognition of the effort to make this more of a community of practice rather than this top down infrastructure of me being the sage or the person in charge.

Most of our liberal studies students if they set foot in a classroom once before they go into their, before they enter the credential program they have to do Ed 50 which is, what, 50 or 60 hours of observation and participation in a classroom, which they typically do in their last semester. But prior to that requirement for entry into the program we have probably the greatest percentage of our students who are never in a classroom setting and who don't have field experience and don't have service learning and aren't looking at teaching as transformation. They're looking at it as a job. In fact I would say if there's one thing I can do before I retire and stop doing anything it would be to have a larger percentage of students understand teaching as a transformative event. That's why I left the classroom because I could only do that in my own space rather than making that happen on a larger scale.

Mini corps is probably the single most amazing entity we have within teacher ed because it's so, not just comprehensive but homegrown. So the people, the students who are in mini corps are working with faculty who once were mini corps who are working with teachers in the community who were once mini corps. So they all have a shared vision and a shared experience. They all come in some way from migrant backgrounds and they all have had experiences in schooling that have been either gatekeeping or people looking at them through a deficit lens. So they've had experiences that they can connect to their own desire to make that not be the case for the next generation of learners. They have the ability that virtually no one else has to connect with children and their families in their homes and their lives in a way that is not top down or condescending. They can talk about their own experience and how the experience that they had had led them to this place in their lives where they're now college students looking at careers in education. It's more valid coming from these students. I mean it's believable, it's real, it's like grassroots change at the very finest.

What I hope I can achieve at some point in my time here is some element of replication of that model at large so that it extends beyond one community. I don't want to change mini corps but I want to replicate mini corps model so that all students have the opportunity to participate and a greater percentage of kids in the communities can interact with students who are learning and being scaffolded and mentored at that level at that point in their careers. Most of our liberal studies students if they set foot in a classroom once before they go into their, before they enter the credential program they have to do Ed 50 which is, what, 50 or 60 hours of observation and participation in a classroom, which they typically do in their last semester. But prior to that requirement for entry into the program we have probably the greatest percentage of our students who are never in a classroom setting and who don't have field experience and don't have service learning and aren't looking at teaching as transformation.

We've got a lot of work to do here because our mini corps students are a small percentage of our students. Wouldn't it be amazing if every student in our program came from a mini corps-ish background, had multiple years of embedded experience in area classrooms and learning about the cultures of the families and learning about the contexts in which our students come from, in which our K-12 students live and being integrated intimately into that world before they go into teaching with that scaffolding and support?

I teach an academic literacy course that I started teaching when I was still adjunct. It's a cohorted model called First Year Experience for 100 students each year. They are the most at risk students on our campus. Every student in this cohort is first generation. Every student in this cohort has met minimum requirements to attend this university but has failed both English and math placement exams. So if they don't remediate within that first year they're not allowed to stay. I get to teach one of their only GE courses that year. Academic reading is a special designation course that they get GE credit for. I get to work with 100 freshmen, 18 year olds, first time, first generation freshmen every year. So I really get to know more about the campus culture than a lot of people but I also work with credential students and grad students in my more typically literacy courses.

The advisors would love to cohort people because it would be easier for everybody and the students would not have to worry about enrolling in classes. They would already have those classes selected for them. The faculty want the opportunity and the time and the space to unpack Common Core, the CSET standards and figure out what their syllabi, how they're missing the mark because we do have a really severe issue with our students not meeting the high stakes barriers and not being able to continue or complete their credentials.

We're very mindful of the fact that we don't want to be top down. We don't want to come in with a deficit lens. We don't want to come in and say there's a situation here and we're the superheroes and we're going to fix it. So it's a delicate balance.

What is on the CSET in your content area and have you looked at it and do you know what students are being asked to do and do you know what that looks in schools and have you worked with a K-8 teacher recently to understand how what you're doing translates pedagogically into the classroom. So we're trying to work in all of these different spheres with the ultimate goal of, yes, this sort of pragmatic gatekeeping device but we don't want to stop there. We don't want to be just go take your test prep course and then you'll be okay and then you can move on with your life and with your job. We want our students who ultimately pass CSET to say hey this is a lot like what students in my classroom will face when the high stakes standardized testing comes through. I'm making decisions about teaching what I know is right versus teaching what I know is on the test and how am I going to walk that tightrope so that my students both have access to the culture of power but also have the ability to resist and to work around it and outside of it.

I'm not the best person to answer this question but I believe that when they enroll as liberal study students in their freshman year or they transfer in their junior year that they are told from the, it's Room 100 downstairs. It's the advising office. They're told of all of the different opportunities that we have for students in liberal studies.

The one thing I say about Fresno State a lot of people in my program thought I was crazy to apply to one school and say the Hail Mary and get in. Most people go on a national search and want to be all over the place. We were already pretty much settled here but beside the fact that I had geography as a factor in my taking the job one thing I say about this place is if you can dream it or imagine it you can make it happen. There is so much opportunity on this campus. If you had a more deficit perspective you might say that there is so much need or there is so much that needs to happen or that should happen here. What I see is just nothing but opportunity and a lot of support for making any kind of change happen.

So what we think in terms of CSET is, yes, they need test prep and there is a lot of talk about test prep and there's a lot of talk about understanding, unpacking it and understanding the content and doing the test practices and all of this other stuff that makes my toes curl. But what we really want them to do is step back from the test one step and understand that it is a barrier and understand historically what this means on a great context and understand what does it mean that the faculty in your liberal studies program who taught the course that was supposed to prepare you for this don't even know what's on that test. Sometimes in order to really make change and be transformative you've got to sort of rally everybody and insight a little bit of frustration about the status quo. The status quo in our opinion is not addressing these needs in a mindful way, in a multitude of context. So our role is we're not just lighting a fire under the mini corps students and telling them hey this kind of blows that they didn't prepare you but we're now also working with all of our liberal studies faculty to ask them the difficult questions.
