When you get to know them they're wonderfully charismatic individuals. They're fun to be around. They have a tradition of oral storytelling and they're just fun. They've got a wonderful disposition and sure a lot of them don't care for what's going on around them but when they're within their element they're fun people to be around, very open, very gregarious. Traditionally when they get into an environment like this with you guys sitting here they'll be very quiet and they won't really open up to you. Much, much more, my gosh, the amount of students either at the high school or here at the college that I have had contact with wonderfully intelligent, extremely intelligent. You just get angry with the situation because they could be anything they wanted to be.

We were very fortunate in terms of accessing consultants to do our grant work for us. What you have to understand is back then we were, the funding was about 70% grant driven and 30% was based on your Indian student capital. That's not a very good scenario. If you're going to live by the grant you're going to die by the grant. The federal government, I'm sure you're all well aware, is not the easiest organization to work with. They could pull the plug at any time when you're going on programs, which comes back to the teacher ed program and where I got started. Unfortunately the Department of Ed so chose to pull that program. So all of the people in that that came through and obtained their degrees and were teaching in the schools, teaching by far and away most of them. I can't say all but most of them were working within the school systems in education. To have that pulled then there was no carrot, there was no focal point. So we had a huge issue in terms of people actually going into teacher education.

We worked really hard to get teacher education back. We all knew that teacher education was a focal point of our communities, by far and away the largest employer, the most significant organizations on these reservations are the school systems, the most vital. If we're not putting Native Americans back into those positions that are being vacated then we're not doing a service to our communities. So we worked hard and eventually it came through shortly before I left the college as president, which was 2004. I don't think we had it when we left. I think it came in right after I left but it was a lot of work. We finally convinced the Department of Ed to put money back into teacher education.

one of the first things we did is we definitely got into Land Grant and Indian construction through RDA. The Department of Ed we kind of created a little scenario in there in which they had no other choice because they had totally done away with construction in the Department of Ed for quite a few years. Every time you went back to ask the Department of Ed of course we don't have the funds for it, we don't have the funds for it. What we did was is we went back and we used the HBCU's an example of what they did, how they used it and how they got what they wanted. Saying, okay, you already set the precedent here. Let's see what we can do. So what they did was, which is typically what they did with the HBCU's too, was is that they opened up their Title III, their Strengthening Institutions Grants. That's where we got our construction dollars. The rest is history. We got it all taken care of but that's kind of where we started. Then we started working on some of these programs like the teacher ed program that we knew were extremely important to our communities and of course eventually that's happened.

The challenges is going to be the traditional socioeconomic issues. We've always had those problems. It used to be manifested in maybe alcohol, maybe a little bit drugs. Now it's becoming very little alcohol and a whole hell of a lot of drugs. Quite an abusive of prescription medicines. Of course having Indian Health Service and their lack of oversight is allowing for an awful lot of drugs to hit the street that otherwise shouldn't. So they're taking full advantage of it. Prescription medicine is another one they can easily explain to their employer. Marijuana or cocaine or anything else, crack. That's kind of hard to explain. But having certain drugs in your system they're like they gave it to me. I went up to the clinic, I had a problem and they gave it to me. So therein lies the dilemma.

Families can be extremely nuclear in its broad structure but very limited in its individual structure. A lot of single parent homes more times than not women centered, the mother. Although there are dads out there as well raising their kids. Of course with a lot of help, both of them. As an example, I have a great granddaughter that lives with my wife and I. We've got custody of her. It's a great granddaughter. And that happens quite frequently, much more so than you care.
No sense of self-worth.

It's engrained. Anywhere they go publicly they are what they are. They're not extremely well received in other communities. In shopping communities, Great Falls, for example, it's not really a border community but it's close enough because that's the nearest great shopping area. Highly misguided ideas of Native Americans in our outlying communities even though we competed against them and, listen, I'm not Native American. I'm as white as you two are, you three are.

The college writing class I had taught the only class in college writing I for a while and of course the class starts out around the 25 to 35 range. But now we've added a second section just to provide more opportunity for them to take it. Because we only teach it once a day you've got time conflicts, you've got issues. So they opened up another section. So it's gone down to 15 to 20. The basic math class is woeful. I'll get 10 maybe, 10 or 12. But there's reasons for that. The introductory college writing course I'll get about the same. The government and US history and history of rock and roll are pretty good. They're up there in the 20's. That's what will start and by the end it's not nearly that.

We were very fortunate in terms of accessing consultants to do our grant work for us. What you have to understand is back then we were, the funding was about 70% grant driven and 30% was based on your Indian student capital. That's not a very good scenario. If you're going to live by the grant you're going to die by the grant. The federal government, I'm sure you're all well aware, is not the easiest organization to work with. They could pull the plug at any time when you're going on programs, which comes back to the teacher ed program and where I got started.Unfortunately the Department of Ed so chose to pull that program. So all of the people in that that came through and obtained their degrees and were teaching in the schools, teaching by far and away most of them. I can't say all but most of them were working within the school systems in education. To have that pulled then there was no carrot, there was no focal point. So we had a huge issue in terms of people actually going into teacher education.

Career Opportunity Program, something like that, was pulled in '74 or '75 maybe. They did have some other funds they accessed for another couple of years. That put a lot of people into education. Then they just pulled it. It just went away. When did we get the teacher education program back here? Ten years ago, at least what I can recall. About ten years ago the teacher education program came back. But that was due to a lot of efforts by AIHEC and it's governing body or all the institutions and especially a couple of individuals I worked really closely with was Joe McDonald out of Salish Kootenai and Jim Shandly out of -0:09:34-. We seemed to be the three amigos who worked very well together. I can't say enough good things about those two guys.

There were a couple of very good agreements that we struck between the Land Grant institutions recognizing the tribal colleges as a Land Grant institution and the Executive Order recognizing the tribal colleges. Both of those in themselves were very, very powerful for us, were very, very powerful pieces of work. Then that gave us the power then to walk back to these departments, walk back to our representatives and say here you've got to step to the plate here. You can't ignore this when it's been signed by the president as far as our Executive Order and Land Grant status. You can't ignore this. It did really open up a lot of doors for funding, target funding, that we otherwise wouldn't have had the opportunity to, we couldn't have gotten. We couldn't have been successful at all except for that document.

When you get to know them they're wonderfully charismatic individuals. They're fun to be around. They have a tradition of oral storytelling and they're just fun. My first foray into education was through a program called, for lack of better words I don't remember exactly what the name was but it was a teacher ed program and I worked at the Rocky Boy Schools for a number of years while we worked towards our baccalaureate degree in education. That was way back in the 70's. Eventually I did finish and then I became a teacher at the high school. They had just started the high school. I left there after a few years to entertain a post graduate degree at MSU Bozeman in school administration. I came back, personal issues, kind of interceded with the direction my wife and I were going in life. So we wound up staying. The problem was that she had already left her or resigned from her teaching position and then she started in the same program that I started with because we had plan on moving. Because of the personal issues we couldn't and she got her job back eventually. I looked around and I found a job at the college. In fact, they approached me. In 1994 is when we started to work for the college. I coordinated and directed a few of the programs for the college at the time.

I teach, I have a remedial math program that I run and I really like that. I've always been a mathematician at heart. But that aside, I teach remedial math, I teach remedial English along with college writing I. I teach the speech class. I teach US history now. I got that back again and government and my favorite class history of rock and roll. So after he came back and I took his textbook and we ran the textbook down and we decided to have a class. It's a fun class. Students love it.

Block A was, as I remember, was science, reading and I don't remember the other subject but there were three subjects. So what we do is usually we are assigned like a school. We don't really observe. We help the teacher with duties sometimes. From the school like from here at New Mexico State they assign us lesson plans. So we implement those lesson plans in our practicum or block but it's depending on the subjects that we do. Block B is a little bit more in-depth where still reading, because we each have reading. We do math and social studies. We do Fount of Knowledge thematic unit. I'm pretty sure you guys have heard of it today. So we just basically go to a student's household, we build a very big thematic unit and we implement it into our block or we try to because sometimes the teachers and depending on what semester we teach and the testing we try to implement as much as we can from the Fount of Knowledge. So that's incorporating student's prior knowledge into the lesson plans.

I: How did you show him that you care? : How I show him that I care is like in Spanish like you know if you bring your homework you're going to do this or you know this is kind of like me doing this is kind of your, because teachers were not getting too upset with me. Like if you don't do this I really care for your learning and you know if you're not doing this you know I get a bad grade too. Like show him that personal connection that I really care for him. I did a lot of ones on ones, one on one and lot of more just at school and connect like what did you do this weekend and so and so like his name and just connect to his background knowledge. Now his mom, I never heard that what the teacher told me that his mom never showed up in school. She shows up to school and if he forgets his homework he'll call her to bring his homework. This is one of the kids that had never brought his homework like in the past. Now he's like Miss I brought my homework. Good job.

F: Right. Just the unit test, the grade level test, today I did a Jeopardy game. So I try to do fun stuff out of that. If they get a good grade I try to reward them. So I try to see the positive for them to see because it feeds off from me if I stress and they feed it like I feed it to them. I just try to do like fun activities. If you guys get a good grade you know we're going to do this or just rewards a lot. So like a lot of rewards so that's how.

F: My greatest concern right now would be just being effective as a teacher to help the students with all the tests and prepare them because they are hard. Right now I am in third grade so it's their first year taking the test. So I see my teacher working very hard to help them and kind of guide them. So I think that would be my issue of concern how to help them.

F: No, he's not but I guess we've been together for like six years and so he's been very supportive with my education. I had to give up a job so he's been supporting me financially. I had some scholarships but he's been good.

I'm not sure. I'm not sure honestly. When I joke with my brothers about it I tell them that being a teacher, in my opinion, is probably one of the hardest jobs ever because of everything that it entails. I feel being a teacher is not ever just being a teacher. You have to fill so many different roles while you're there. You could possibly be a mom, possibly be a dad or confidant or a person to give the students a little love or even respect. On top of that you have to get different information locked into their heads, math, reading, language arts, science all while doing all of these other things that I've already stated. Even just to refer back to my internship at Clemson, it will take a toll. We call it the look of death and we joked about it. But almost every day when we got done with working like we would just on the bus and everybody would be quiet. This is a full bus mind you, just drive on back to campus, get back on campus and just go to sleep. It really takes it out of you.

A good teacher would be a successful transfer of accurate knowledge between the students, from me to the students. I feel like that's a good way to determine. That's one reason the teacher, well not the only reason, but a main reason the teacher is there to help give them knowledge so they can learn and be able to do more with the knowledge that they're given. I feel if you can spit something out to them and they can spit it right back out and it still lines up correctly then I would believe that that's a job well done. I also think it takes time. During the internship that's what my supervisor was sure to tell me about. It just takes time. I kept asking questions as to how to work with this type of personality or this type of student or this behavior. They were telling me that a lot of things I was asking about is really a learning process versus a moment.

M: Yes. I think that's a piece of it. I'm not going to say that because I'm an African American male that that's all there is to it. I think that while that it is a piece another thing is they simply don't know. They don't have any idea or clue about myself or any other male, whoever is walking in. From what I've gathered that's how students operate because once you're a teacher then they'll start figuring, they'll really start figuring you out. Something was told in the internship if you do not get them before they get you you're in trouble.
After the first year of being involved with this program we're required to go to an internship in South Carolina Clemson where Call Me MISTER first originated.

During all throughout the process I kept having these realizations because I've been accustomed to being a student. To stand up in front of a classroom with nobody else just you in front of a classroom and you're the teacher now it was a shock. It was a shock. So I had to keep my mind rolling because I would like to dwell on it for a little bit longer to just really let it soak in. The children, the students, I won't call them children. The students are right in front of you. You don't have time to try to process that because they're waiting on you. That was just different all together.

having an African American male in the classroom I'm going to call it a rare sight. Maybe since so many children only have that one experience it molds, like they build and add to that image whether it's good or bad about that teacher, about other African American male teachers. If it was negative then they're adding to a negative image. If it was positive of course then vice versa. I would say, yes, but if I am effective and if I'm not effective either I have to get it together or find a new profession.

I feel if you can spit something out to them and they can spit it right back out and it still lines up correctly then I would believe that that's a job well done. I also think it takes time.

different people that I've run into different children, even students, even adults, who I have been able to teach something new. Not even to say that I was trying to teach them per se but by the end of that I had a new revelation on something or the other. As I thought about that I realized that teaching is important to me because it's always happening. I don't think you can get away from it whether you're teaching yourself of teaching other people. With that being said, I think I would want to work on my teaching skills considering it's going to happen so that when I do teach I could say that I've taught well, like very good.

M: I'd like to get my master's because I don't want to stop. I feel like if I took a break or stopped I don't know how long it would be before I actually came back. I do feel at some point it's going to come in handy.
M: I will have taught for four years. I'm going to teach in Mississippi. I will have taught for four years in Mississippi.

M: She recommended it to me because she just wanted me to do what I have set out to do. During my high school career I had made different goals that I wanted to accomplish or different things that I felt the school I wanted had to have. One was I wanted to attend a HBCU. I wanted to experience the south. That was what I constantly referred to, experience the south and I wanted to get away from home. But during the process there were many schools that I got accepted to but I didn't have the funds. At that time I didn't think of Jackson State as an option. So as the time was winding down to get ready for new incoming freshman to move on, to move out, I was still undecided. As you can imagine stress was just rising. My mom suggested Jackson State because my oldest brother actually went here for a year before he went into the military. Fortunately was able to send in the paperwork, call people, and I had received late admission and thanks to my mom I was even able to receive a scholarship at that. Then a couple of weeks from then or maybe even that next week because it was a short time. Mom drove me down here and hello to Jackson State.
M: I did. My favorite teacher, Mr. Allie. I had him 4th grade. I did not have him 5th grade but I had him 4th grade.

No, it's okay. I'll answer both. But that's just a different angle for me why do I care about teaching. Why do I care? Not even to say that I was trying to teach them per se but by the end of that I had a new revelation on something or the other. As I thought about that I realized that teaching is important to me because it's always happening. I don't think you can get away from it whether you're teaching yourself of teaching other people. With that being said, I think I would want to work on my teaching skills considering it's going to happen so that when I do teach I could say that I've taught well, like very good.

Let's see, maybe a good lunch. Maybe those things are like minute, like little things that just make you want to keep doing it. But I feel that every teacher has to find that reason beside the fact that it's the job. I know that's how it happened for me.

After the first year of being involved with this program we're required to go to an internship in South Carolina Clemson where Call Me MISTER first originated.

It was grueling because at first when we first got there it was just meeting after meeting after meeting after meeting, almost like a general assembly and almost like a job. We'll go there early and we'll have to stay there until about late. You had different people coming in and talking, giving speeches and trying to help us understand how they feel about education and their aspect of it. Some lady was talking about different important rules and regulations and another person was just talking about maybe some small nuances you might run into or their personal experience. There were graduates who also came back and was able to speak on their experience through the program and exactly where they are now. Then the immerging process where we were divided up and we were sent to a summer camp or a shelter and we had to be teachers there. That's where I received my first class of 4th and 5th graders.
M: I am born and raised in Indianapolis, Indiana. Indianapolis, Indiana. How I got to Jackson State though however, Jackson State was a recommendation by my mom.

M: She recommended it to me because she just wanted me to do what I have set out to do. During my high school career I had made different goals that I wanted to accomplish or different things that I felt the school I wanted had to have. One was I wanted to attend a HBCU. I wanted to experience the south. That was what I constantly referred to, experience the south and I wanted to get away from home. But during the process there were many schools that I got accepted to but I didn't have the funds. At that time I didn't think of Jackson State as an option. So as the time was winding down to get ready for new incoming freshman to move on, to move out, I was still undecided. As you can imagine stress was just rising. My mom suggested Jackson State because my oldest brother actually went here for a year before he went into the military. Fortunately was able to send in the paperwork, call people, and I had received late admission and thanks to my mom I was even able to receive a scholarship at that. Then a couple of weeks from then or maybe even that next week because it was a short time. Mom drove me down here and hello to Jackson State.

So this kind of goes into how I got introduced to the Call Me MISTER program. It so happened that during the undecided major orientation our supervisor, Dr. Latiker, he just so happened to be talking about the program. After he got done talking I talked with him for a while and asking him question after question like really drilling the program to make sure it was ethical. Everything checked out so I went through the process, interviewed and I'm in the Call Me MISTER program and thus began really my major interest in teacher. Since I've been in Call Me MISTER it's really made me reconsider the whole idea of teaching.

: It sounded, at first it sounded like it was too good to be true. The way he was talking about it he was saying that I guess the benefits that came with the program was that you're going to be paid for between your tuition, your books and I guess maybe it was just the way that he was able to dress it up, you know, pitch it to you. That's what I meant. I didn't want to get in, if he wasn't able to answer all the questions I felt pertinent and figuring out exactly what this program is about then I wouldn't have jumped on board, if you will. But that's what I meant when I said ethical.
After the first year of being involved with this program we're required to go to an internship in South Carolina Clemson where Call Me MISTER first originated.

the benefits that came with the program was that you're going to be paid for between your tuition, your books
At this point I do realize that the need for African American teachers is high. I do realize that. But for me personally I'm still in this program with my cohort members, my brothers

It means that I've accepted them as my brothers. In the program like the program has different tenets and one focus is being a brother's keeper. This is my second year being in the program. My first year I wasn't doing that well because I was about self-development, self-development and getting myself through the program, being able to not assert myself into a position but make myself seen so that I can continue to progress. Even though I was doing that and I can do it well I wasn't taking care to recognize my brothers. Because even though I was in a program with other members I was still an individual and that was how I looked at it. We are individuals under an umbrella, if you will. At this point as I've come to learn, learn and grow, I'm really taking steps to be more responsible like talking with them more and hanging out and really getting to know these other people in the program so that they're not other people. We're friends, friends, associates and even as you come along we're brothers.

Yes, thank you. Parliamentarian, thank you about that. And then you have your secretary. Then to break it down even farther you have people for each individual cohort. Like for Cohort 1 they have a vice president, I mean a president and vice president, parliamentarian and secretary. The same goes for Cohorts 1, 2 and 3 and so on and so forth as the new people come in, new cohorts come in

I wanted to become president because I felt it was my duty to help this program succeed, to help the program succeed and keep continuing to grow on a good path. Not to mention another booster to that was during the time I was in South Carolina, let me just say this real quick. In South Carolina there are cohorts from all over the country that come there that are Call Me MISTER. We all come back and gather together and get to meet and greet each other and you establish relationships that way. By the end of it like some of the seniors of the Call Me MISTER program they would just let me know that I also have to do what I can to encourage the program, to make it better than what it is, to make it better. I took up that charge. During that time we were speaking about it and that was what really pushed me to try to become president. Group consensus of the cohort members the president I'm sure you'll meet him soon. He got it rightfully, got the position rightfully and I'm perfectly okay with being vice president.

M: Yes. Yes, there were plenty of people, plenty of people to be able to talk to and on top of that we would discuss that in our general assembly and even in our camp meeting. Different individuals in certain camps, yes, constantly talking about that. Our supervisors would take like little notes to let us know what they liked or what they didn't like and just pretty much tried to help us understand the different things that we could probably work on. But they were also like very liberal too. Call Me MISTER encourages you as a teacher to develop your uniqueness, that thing that's unique to you like why you're in the classroom because that will most definitely benefit you.

we're being a teacher for students, the members of Call Me MISTER, we're still also finding ourselves, trying to develop our own person and establish ourselves. That's probably a struggle because we have to be these things for our students but we also have to, we have to do something for ourselves as well.

It's people who work, yes. It's normally for it to be flexible for them for people who work. So it was kind of like a mix of everything and then we were in an I-TV system. So there was different campuses like Alamogordo, Grants and Carlsbad. So that was kind of fun to see the others because it worked really well just to see them on screen. I felt a little lost because I felt like I wasn't at my level. We had a lot of discussions and conversations and I feel like I could bring in something to the conversation but then there was just people who have a lot of experience that I felt sometimes that I was like oh I haven't been in a classroom that much. There were some even that were already teachers but they just needed like their license. So I felt like I wasn't that, that I should be very professional when it came to all of this work that we had to do. The workload is a lot heavier definitely. I was very stressed last semester and this semester has been just fine. We were only five hours a week in the classroom, I guess. We had to complete just 50 hours for the semester.

I do. I think some of the biggest challenges are just, I've just heard a lot about standardized testing and all this I guess political kind of things going around education. So I think it's a challenge to just concentrate on doing what you do because you love it and just teaching from the heart. I'm obviously following the curriculum but not, teachers are kind of stressed taking all of the external factors that are going around and I think the essence of what teaching is and teaching at this school for example I feel a lot of the kids come from families that might be a little problematic or a little broken up. So I really like to take in all that more into my teaching as well because kids don't have it at home. So just taking into account all of those differences and we learned a lot about diversity and all these things that you have to take into account. So I think the challenge is just to kind of like teach the essentials and taking in all that diversity and all the needs of your students instead of all the external factors that might stray away from the essentials.

Time passes so quick because I'm always doing something. You're not just sitting there. I can always feel free to walk around the kids. They're always set in groups and you always know which are the groups who are struggling and you sit down with a teacher and she lets you know okay I need you to focus on these kids and he's having trouble with this math and this. So it's kind of like, there's three teachers in that classroom and there's only like 14 students. So we kind of rotate. I feel like I'm always doing something. Even if I'm not teaching I'll always be with a group and walking around and helping and clearing things up. It's a bilingual class or I'm in a Spanish one.

I really like teaching in my language. I had never done it before and I have the opportunity here and I love it because I can help those students who are struggling with both languages and you can just do a lot of things. It's great being in the classroom. You're always active.

I haven't heard it mentioned in the seminars since we only have it once a week. We kind of just concentrate, it's a two hour seminar it's like okay whatever our subject is we target that and that's all we concentrate. But in the evening block since we had a lot more time for discussion topics always came up. We would be there probably for an hour talking about all the norms and the governor and this and education. It's like a whole other thing. We talk a lot about it but it really doesn't get us anywhere. We just complain. I mean I don't really complain because I don't really know what it's about to tell you the truth. I don't feel like I'm prepared to just complain about things. I need to be more informed. But I know there was just a lot of complaining and arguing and stuff about it. Here with my teacher she tells us a lot about what's going on like oh did you hear they're going to do like a strike or kind of like a march for the PARCC test which they're doing now and things like that.

F: So I've kind of had a different experience because my first block was the evening so I didn't have a lot of time in the classroom. I was only there once a week. So this semester has been great. I was very lucky to have an awesome teacher. She knows a lot. She has a lot of experience and she's willing to help us because I'm with another student and we're kind of co-teaching so it's two of us in the classroom. It's a small class and I thought it was kind of, I didn't know why they put two of us there. Maybe because last semester I was in a class with 30 students and it was me alone. But it's been going great.

I'm in fourth grade. At first I was placed in kinder and I was so excited. I was ready for it. I just walk in the classroom and I fall in love with the students and then they changed me because they didn't know I was bilingual because I'm not taking the bilingual endorsement. But then they asked me do you Spanish and I'm like yeah it's kind of like my first language. So they were like oh we need you in another class. So that was like oh okay because last year I was in fifth grade. But it's been going really well. I feel like I've been doing a lot, I've been teaching a lot and I was actually commenting with some of the students that I like this semester a lot better because the teachers seem to be more laid back. They are doing testing but they are reviewing a lot. So I told her I need to do this lesson for this class and she's like any topic you want. I have this list. They need a review on everything. You choose whatever you want, whatever book, very flexible. I feel like if I would have been here last semester it would have been like okay we need to be on task to finish everything on time. So right now it's kind of just like a review of the whole year. So they're very flexible and I really like it. The teacher lets us do a lot. She just so confident that we're kind of ready, I guess. I really like that. They just throw us to the sharks like okay go ahead and teach. So I'm really enjoying the practicum experience. I feel like I have done a lot in the classroom this semester.

F: Sure. I got into the evening block because I registered late and I got into the education program late. So they kind of like okay just put me in there. There wasn't any spots in the on-site. The classes are in the evening. They're from, it's like a 2 ½ hour seminar and it works like this kind of like where we have four seminars and the evening one works once a week and here it's once a month for each seminar. It's mostly students, for me it was a little difficult because I feel like I'm young kind of. I'm starting college and there was a lot of like there were some masters students and there was a lot of parents.

That was pretty flexible. You can choose whenever you wanted and I always chose to go on Thursdays like all morning. That would work for me because I worked all the other days. So that was a little hard because I only got whatever that teacher was doing on Thursdays, say it was only math for the morning and that was it. Here I've gotten a little bit of everything and maybe if she doesn't do science by the time I get here she'll say oh do science one morning so you guys can have a little taste of that. So I feel like I didn't get such a broad spectrum on all the subjects. We mostly did math when I was there. You don't get to teach a lot. I felt like I was observing most of the time. The teacher I got she was very good and she taught me a lot and she helped me a lot but I felt like it was more observation even if it was still a practicum. The evening classes the teachers were great and a lot of the things I learned I've been applying here. So I really like that. But I would definitely prefer the on-site but if it's convenient for others to take that evening block then I guess it just depends on each person. Since I didn't have a lot of experience in the classroom I prefer this one but some of the others had already been in the classroom as substitute teachers and had all of that so it's kind of like a break for them. So I think it just depends on the level you're at.

This December I was in India and for a month I volunteered in Delhi at a school and Calcutta with The Sisters of Charity with people with disabilities. I studied abroad in Germany and in Italy and I traveled through all of Europe. When I did my volunteer right after high school I was working a year in Rhode Island at a boarding school. I was a dean of discipline and it was like a Catholic boarding school for all girls. Then I was in Mexico at another Catholic school.

was working at a school and actually a lot of the things that I have learned here I could take there. It was not only to give my time but also leave something for them. I made them kind of a Common Core Standard thing that the kids should be learning at the grade level they're at. It was just a school in a slum area which is very informal. So it was not just getting my like if you can help us out with a curriculum or something and I just got, I didn't even take my laptop or anything over there. It was just like with what I had like my phone and I had been emailing the people from here because they're like from an NGO over there in India. So actually a lot of things that I've learned here I applied over there.

F: Yes. Or I'm thinking I might go back to Mexico or work at a Special Education like more centered school. So I'm not so sure but this experience is shaping my ideas for my future.

I decided to study education because since I was little I just have that, not something with children but we kind of like attract each other and I just have a lot of patience. I have two younger siblings and I have a lot of cousins, big families in Mexico. So I've always been around children and I feel that I have a lot of patience especially with children with special needs. I just kind of have that need, that want to just help. So that's kind of like a little seed in my heart was like I want to be generous, I want to do something for others but that I can also have like a professional education. So I thought education was the way to go. I actually didn't go into it right after high school because I wasn't sure. I was also think like a lot of comments like education oh like that's really easy to be a teacher. Why don't you study biology or something else? So I kind of was like oh should I be a teacher or not, should I maybe do it as a second major maybe and study something else? So I volunteered for two years and I was volunteering at schools as a formation assistant for girls. That's when I started just loving education and loving being around kids and just teaching them, not only directly but also indirectly like values and stuff with the way I act, I guess. So that's when I decided to go into education.

But I would definitely prefer the on-site but if it's convenient for others to take that evening block then I guess it just depends on each person. Since I didn't have a lot of experience in the classroom I prefer this one but some of the others had already been in the classroom as substitute teachers and had all of that so it's kind of like a break for them.

This December I was in India and for a month I volunteered in Delhi at a school and Calcutta with The Sisters of Charity with people with disabilities. I studied abroad in Germany and in Italy and I traveled through all of Europe. When I did my volunteer right after high school I was working a year in Rhode Island at a boarding school. I was a dean of discipline and it was like a Catholic boarding school for all girls. Then I was in Mexico at another Catholic school.

when I came in to NMSU like right after my freshman year I could study abroad right after you have a year here. So I went through a program through the study abroad office. I was away for seven months and that was great. Then I got a scholarship for that and just looked for financial aid and all that stuff. So it wasn't that hard. It's just a matter of wanting to do it and you can do it. Then for India last semester in December I also when through NMSU. It was a program called Aggies Go Global. They're actually apart from study abroad but it's like an organization that helps you do volunteer work abroad that does not pertain to any like they don't give you any credits for it but its whatever you're studying like for your subject area or your major. There's anything you can do so since I'm an education major I just went there and I'm like okay I want to do something with kids and education. You just look for a program that fits you and that's great. You can choose the date, you can choose whatever you want to do and in whatever part of the world and they'll pay for your airfare and a lot of the things. So it's just a matter of looking for it. A lot of people are like oh it's too expensive to go. You just need to look for things and I promise you that they're there. The opportunities are there. You just need to look for them. So that was an opportunity.

this semester has helped me in that to just kind of talk with my teachers on the breaks where the kids have probably block which is like oh that's inconvenient. it's an amazing campus. It's just having that connection and communication with the people that you meet. At first I was a little intimidated. it's really rewarding. The first year that I worked at the middle school I was working with, because we concentrate with those students that are at risk basically. it's so rewarding to see that you're making that improvement with those students that you're inspiring them to get where they're going. It feels like a family to be honest. It really does feel like a family. You really get to know your peers and it's amazing because we always talk about the classes we're taking. But, yes, it's just, it's a different feeling, a different feeling. I feel like I belong here, I want to say. Yes, just being here with my sister. he's just all around great person and there's, my students -0:20:10.7- most of them do come from farm labor background, like I do, and some of them sometimes don't have pencils, or paper, or notebooks. We spend countless hours in the classroom. We spend way more hours in the classroom than a student teacher would. And you pick up on different strategies. My first teacher I worked with, she was the strict time, that I want it quiet, I want the room quiet, type. And I learned great classroom management from her. Her lessons were concise, and they were just flawless lessons. But what she took from me, what she took away from me, well not away from me, but what she took from me was that to be a little bit more compassionate with the students and not just we're here to learn, and I clock off at 2:30, so she started staying and decorating the classroom, and I would stay with her and help her decorate sometimes as well. And, she also changed in the way that she started doing more fun lessons, and started to smile more, laugh more. I took a lot from her as well because she taught me how to conduct the classroom, how to manage my students, the importance of a routine with the students, get used to having routine and they know after a while, they pick up on it, and they're … they lack, some students lack structure, and they lack that at home. So they like coming to school and knowing that there's structure, and that there's discipline, because that's when they're able to perform better and they're able to show who they really are, and don't get distracted by other students or other distractions.

it's also a connection I want to make with my students. I want to be able to bring in things that make them feel comfortable, make them feel like they're at home because that's when learning takes place the most, I believe. When the students are nervous, and they go and they see I don't belong here, that's something that I don't want my students to feel. I want them to feel like they belong in the classroom, that we're a family, that we're a unit, so that they can learn and it's … in my opinion, that just makes learning easier, because they're open to new ideas and they'll create …

And that's something that I want to bring to the classroom. I want to bring hands-on experiences, experiments, not just reading and writing. I want them to read and write for a cause, for something that they can use in the real world. That's something that I've learned from my professors here as well.

How I got into teaching was actually my, one of my older sisters, she's a teacher at Parlier Unified. And when she starts at Fresno State, she joined Mini-Corps, and she was in Mini-Corps throughout her whole college career. t just opened my eyes to how I could help students. I started at my first school I started working at was a rural school, in a rural area, called Orange Center. And also, when I was in 6th Grade, I had a Mini-Corps tutor in my classroom and I wasn't aware that she was a Mini-Corps tutor. I was in the Migrant Program. And, she would come in every day and help us, help a small group of migrant students with math, and I just thought it was a college student doing some community service or doing her hours. And I remember, this is what I like about this program aside from the academics, the Mini-Corps tutors, there's something about it, just something special, and this I remember that we had a pizza party and I had … I didn't bring money that day but we had to each pay part of our pizza so we could get to participate in the party, and I actually didn't bring money that day and she went out to her car, and as a college student now I know that sometimes it is kind of hard on the pocket, it's she went out to her car and she actually brought in what she had, and she paid for me so I could participate in that party. And later on, actually my first year in Mini-Corps, I found out she was a Mini-Corps student, and I saw her again. I thanked her a lot. And it's just something different aside from teachers in the credential program or other programs.

It's just they, I don't know, it's something different from with Mini-Corps tutors, and it's something I saw from her that she wasn't there just to teach us but she was there to create that rapport, to create that bond.

I want to be able to bring in things that make them feel comfortable, make them feel like they're at home because that's when learning takes place the most, I believe.

I want them to feel like they belong in the classroom, that we're a family, that we're a unit, so that they can learn and it's … in my opinion, that just makes learning easier, because they're open to new ideas and they'll create …

But, yes, it's just, it's a different feeling, a different feeling. I feel like I belong here, I want to say. And since I had family here, my first year actually, it was the last year of one of my sisters, and I felt like I belonged here because I got to meet her friends, and then I had my friends from high school, or friends from middle school that we didn't go to the same high school, and elementary school, and you just feel like you connect automatically and that you belong with the people here, and it's a great atmosphere in this school.

And my mom, I love my mom, and every time I would say that I was going to leave and that I was getting ready to leave, she would just start weeping and crying, and I just couldn't do it to my mom. I couldn't break her heart like that. And both of my sisters had come here to Fresno State, and I said I'll go to Fresno State then, I don't want my mom to suffer. So, I stayed here and I'm glad I made that choice, even though my life probably would have been way different living on the coast, living on Monterey Bay. But, I don't regret my decision of staying at Fresno State.

Ms. -0:19:16.7- is an angel, what do you mean by that?M: She's great. She really looks out for the students. When she comes and visits us, she asks if there are students that are in need, or how the students are doing, and she's just, she's an angel, she's very endearing. She's like my second mother. Yes, just being here with my sister. And that's something that I want to bring to the classroom. I want to bring hands-on experiences, experiments, not just reading and writing. I want them to read and write for a cause, for something that they can use in the real world. That's something that I've learned from my professors here as well.

Yes, they've never had a foot on a university and I feel like bringing them to campus it bridges that gap that they have. Like I said, most of their parents didn't go, didn't continue studying. My parents stopped. I believe my dad stopped in 6th Grade back in Mexico, and my mom in 2nd Grade. So that push to go to college wasn't always there. But once my older sister came to college, it was expected of me as well to go to the university. So first of all, I would like to bring them in the field trip and show them all of the neat things that the university offers.

with Mini-Corps, I've been working with this program for four years now, and I've been lucky enough to get in another program called Teaching Fellows. And with Teaching Fellows, I've gotten a great position, Assistant Coordinator of an Afterschool Program.

Just the way, there's a lot of lessons actually, and we do in-services monthly. And, they bring every, with Common Core, we actually started learning about Common Core before it was implemented in Fresno Unified, and we had Common Core trainings. And we know that Common Core is not bubble and the answer, we're giving the students the tools, we're providing them with the tools for them to be able to do something with the problem not just say oh 2+2, circle, and bubble in. we know that we're saying if Sally has 2 apples, and Joe has 2 apples, bring them together, or if they put up a stand, how will they contribute each to the product, or to the income of the stand, or something.

it's my passion, and I would coach soccer for them, for the students. And, I would do tutoring, and I would spend time with an afterschool program. I would help them with their homework. And if they didn't understand a lesson that was taught at the regular school, I would provide that supplemental instruction, and I would go into the library, and I would help them with that. And that just changed my outlook on teaching and on the program, and also meeting as I said in the monthly in-services with the other Mini-Corps.

We spend countless hours in the classroom. We spend way more hours in the classroom than a student teacher would. And you pick up on different strategies. My first teacher I worked with, she was the strict time, that I want it quiet, I want the room quiet, type. And I learned great classroom management from her. Her lessons were concise, and they were just flawless lessons. But what she took from me, what she took away from me, well not away from me, but what she took from me was that to be a little bit more compassionate with the students and not just we're here to learn, and I clock off at 2:30, so she started staying and decorating the classroom, and I would stay with her and help her decorate sometimes as well. And, she also changed in the way that she started doing more fun lessons, and started to smile more, laugh more. I took a lot from her as well because she taught me how to conduct the classroom, how to manage my students, the importance of a routine with the students, get used to having routine and they know after a while, they pick up on it, and they're … they lack, some students lack structure, and they lack that at home. So they like coming to school and knowing that there's structure, and that there's discipline, because that's when they're able to perform better and they're able to show who they really are, and don't get distracted by other students or other distractions.

t just opened my eyes to how I could help students. I started at my first school I started working at was a rural school, in a rural area, called Orange Center. And, the students there, most of them are migrant students. They all come from a diverse background. They're all Hispanic or Hmong. And, I just saw how much I could help the students and the impact I can make in their lives, and it changed my outlook on what I really wanted to do, because science, it is important and it's something that I have great passion towards. But seeing how I could change the students and I can help them make life-long learners, and I can help them like learning, that was just something different and something that I really enjoyed. And also, when I was in 6th Grade, I had a Mini-Corps tutor in my classroom and I wasn't aware that she was a Mini-Corps tutor. I was in the Migrant Program. And, she would come in every day and help us, help a small group of migrant students with math, and I just thought it was a college student doing some community service or doing her hours. And I remember, this is what I like about this program aside from the academics, the Mini-Corps tutors, there's something about it, just something special, and this I remember that we had a pizza party and I had … I didn't bring money that day but we had to each pay part of our pizza so we could get to participate in the party, and I actually didn't bring money that day and she went out to her car, and as a college student now I know that sometimes it is kind of hard on the pocket, it's she went out to her car and she actually brought in what she had, and she paid for me so I could participate in that party. And later on, actually my first year in Mini-Corps, I found out she was a Mini-Corps student, and I saw her again. I thanked her a lot. And it's just something different aside from teachers in the credential program or other programs.

but we're there for each other when we need it. We are all in the same class and if I'm struggling on something they'll help me out. If I know something that they're struggling on I'll there to help them out. We are helping and like to remind each other, like I said, if I don't go to class I'll get four or five phone calls from different people why I'm not in class, when I'll be in class. If I just have like a dentist appointment I always tell one of them, tell the teacher I'm not going to be there, get my work from them. It's like business to be close and as we go through the program we are getting closer and we learn from each other on how to deal with each other and help each other out.

My biggest thing is the social like how do people view and the income of a teacher. Teachers don't get paid that much but it grows. It just depends on your resume. I can tell you can go into the school district to get paid $70,000 to be a teacher versus going to school and get paid $35,000 for a teacher. You've got to build your resume up to the $70,000 year a teacher where they actually want you to be a teacher in that position.

I tell them male teachers have impact and I tell them how we done research. It's not the male, like all teachers not bad teachers and I'm not a pedophile. I don't want to mess with you and I want to help the children. I actually have a love to teach children so I'm not going to be that teacher that touches on kids or anything like that. But some people have that viewpoint oh you just want to be around little children and like I don't think that's necessary like you think you're being ignorant saying stuff like that.
Yes, ma'am. And I also had like most of the teachers they keep say oh all the man teachers they're gay and stuff like that. No. That's how people think. That's stereotypes that come along with it.

I've got Call Me MISTER support and Dr. Latiker. If I have family problems Dr. Latiker talks to me about it and he's like they're not understanding you now but you're in school and you're going to be somebody and you're going to have a good career. I tried the military but I failed it and so I'm in school. I'm just not doing nothing so even if they don't like it now they're going to like it later when I'm actually doing something and making an impact.

Usually in high school you just pull something off the internet and do it but actually we had to go out to the different schools and talk to the different teachers and interview them, sit down and interview them and see how the kids reacted to them. So it was really, I felt like I was actually doing research instead of using somebody else's research. I feel like I was doing something important.

Monday you go to class, meet up, do our homework. Tuesday's wake up, go to our book buddies and then we go to teach the kids. Then we'll go to class. Wednesday sometimes we might have like a conference or we have a meeting with people and talk to us and do our Praxis prep and our core test preps. Thursday we have our weekly meeting with all of the MISTER's and our academic coach. We talk about our experience and our week and what's going on and what's coming up and what's past and what we need to prepare for and whatnot. Friday is really more of a relaxed day. You get ready for the weekend. Sometimes Saturdays we have conference or other events we have to do. So no week is the same but we always know what we've got to do ahead of time what we need to do

Usually in high school you just pull something off the internet and do it but actually we had to go out to the different schools and talk to the different teachers and interview them, sit down and interview them and see how the kids reacted to them. So it was really, I felt like I was actually doing research instead of using somebody else's research. I feel like I was doing something important.

Dr. Latiker he told us the deadlines. Actually he just told us the deadline and we chose the title because we're in Call Me MISTER and we're going to be black African American males teachers. So we decided let's see how this other black African American elementary school teachers impact their kids. So he just told us okay it's something you need to do and teachers get interviewed from. He just told us that so it was up to us to actually go out to the different schools, find the African American male teachers and interview them.

I sat down in the class and the teacher that hated his job his children were running him wild and then you go down the hallway in the next block and the same kids go to the next male teacher's class and they're perfect students and sitting down and being quiet. I was talking to Dr. Latiker about it and he was like it's always about classroom management and how you come off to the kids. They'll respect you and they'll like you then they'll behave and listen to you. I ain't going to say his name but the teacher down the hall he had a problem with his kid. He was like because he don't do nothing fun. He just sit down and talk to the kids and tell them to do this and do that. But see I'm up talking to my kids and interacting with them and helping them out and it is not a boring class period. That's why they listen to me and like learning. His class had nothing else to do but be bad and misbehave because they be bored. So it's pretty diverse and depending on the teacher.

I really want to be a principal and then work up to being like something higher than the principal, probably on the board for the district, probably work up to being that. I'll probably do like three or four years doing it and probably in three or four years I'll probably have my master's degree. So then I'd be able to apply to being a principal over a school. If you end up being a principal you get to work with more kids and see more kids. So I think I'd have a greater impact with the kids like that.

What really interested me into teaching is when I got to Jackson State I applied and I was going to do undecided major. But then they came in, Dr. Latiker came in and he was telling me about the Call Me MISTER scholarship and the program and what it's about. So then he tells me to sit down and think about like throughout my education was there any male teacher that impacted my life. To be honest it was. In kindergarten and middle school and in high school it was always that male figure that helped me stay out of trouble and motivate me to finish school. So I want to give back like he told me like I should give back and be that male and role model to somebody else.

had the little kids like the elementary kids. It was funny. I was working with this one guy during the summer and before I left he was like I wish you could be my dad or my stepdad. He was like my dad never do this and my dad never reads with me and you're fun. He was bold enough to tell me that. How many other kids am I reaching that haven't told me that yet? It shows that we actually do make an impact because when we're not there we actually have teachers say we had a child who was looking for you. I had a dentist appointment. I usually work with a certain group of kids and they were where he at, where he at. So when I got back they all yay we missed you. So it's probably five or six kids to the classroom and 30 or 28 kids waiting to learn and to see my face. You can be a big impact.

Dr. Latiker he's our academics coach but I'm going to say he's one of the people who, he goes beyond his job. Even though we have to call him about something that's not dealing with school like I had a flat tire. I could call Dr. Latiker and he's be able to come and help me out if I need like advice dealing with relationships or family problems. He'll give me advice. He's really like a big brother or father or uncle to everybody. Whatever we need him to be he's there for us and he also helps us with our work whenever we need it. When we do a paper and we're not sure about the paper we can always email him the paper and he'll proofread it and he'll tell us you've got these mistakes and you need to go back and look over this. And like math when are you free? Okay, you're free Thursday at 1:00. Okay, I'll have a math tutor waiting for you. Make sure you'll be there. And say if we have an event coming up he'll email us to tell us about our event, what we need to do, what we need wear and what time we can meet up and all of the basic details about it. He's also the same person that tells us what you need to do about showing and you need to do this and do that or there's going to be consequences.

From Call Me MISTER and other people around here. It's not just Call Me MISTER but it's other males and other teachers and administrators and people that see us working. We go to the schools and work with the kids. Anyone who teachers there we need advice or we need community service hours, observation hours. They're always there to help. If we have a question about this coming up at high school and how teaching is going to be and the class is going to be they're going to help us out. All of them looking forward to seeing us teaching and want to see us doing good. So can't let nobody down and we've always got to help so I think I'm getting enough helping hands to impact me to be the best and get all the good information from all the teachers and their past experience to make me the best I can be.

It has a reputation for that and a good reputation for that because I think administrators and principals throughout the vicinity take note of where you're coming from. I think they see as a positive that you get your credentials here at Fresno State versus National University of Fresno Pacific just because of the rigorous program that this university has in place. I saw a great disconnect between the staff and the students that they're serving. Most of them are not acquainted with the struggles that the students are facing. I think just the time and effort it takes and then just getting there. I think it's just getting there. It's taking time. It's taking time and it's really hard because of finances. my 8th grade history teacher who is now the principal at the junior high.
